headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Chubb Corporation's Fourth Quarter 2014 Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded.Before we begin, Chubb has asked me to make the following statements: In order to help you understand Chubb, its indu
componenttext:
Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Chubb Corporation's Fourth Quarter 2014 Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded.
Before we begin, Chubb has asked me to make the following statements: In order to help you understand Chubb, its industries and its results, members of Chubb's management team will include in today's presentation forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. It is possible that actual results might differ from estimates and forecasts that Chubb's management team makes today. Additional information regarding factors that could cause such differences appears in Chubb's filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
In their prepared remarks and responses to questions during today's presentation, Chubb's management may refer to financial measures that are not derived from generally accepted accounting principles or GAAP. Reconciliations of these non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measures and related information are provided in a press release in the financial supplement for the fourth quarter 2014, which are available on the Investors section of Chubb's website at www.chubb.com.
Please note that no portion of this conference call may be reproduced or rebroadcast in any form without Chubb's prior written consent. Replays of this webcast will be available through Friday, February 27, 2015. Those listening after January 29, 2015, should please note that the information and forecast provided in this recording will not necessarily be updated and it is possible that the information will no longer be current.
Now I will turn the call over to Mr. Finnegan.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you for joining us. In the fourth quarter of 2014, Chubb had record operating income per share of $2.29. Net income per share was $2.35. This capped off another great year with operating income per share of $7.63 for the full year and net income per
componenttext:
Thank you for joining us. In the fourth quarter of 2014, Chubb had record operating income per share of $2.29. Net income per share was $2.35. This capped off another great year with operating income per share of $7.63 for the full year and net income per share of $8.62, each of these being the second-best result in Chubb history. As you recall, 2013 earnings per share was the best in our history. So great back-to-back performance reflecting superior underwriting execution.
Our combined ratio for the fourth quarter was 84.3%, the best combined ratio for any quarter in the past 6 years and a 1.2-point improvement over the year early in fourth quarter. The impact of catastrophe losses in the 2014 fourth quarter was 0.8 point compared to 2.1 points in the fourth quarter of 2013. On an x cap basis, our combined ratio was 83.5%, essentially the same as in the fourth quarter of 2013. 
Premiums worldwide were up 3% in the quarter or up 4% excluding the impact of currency. As in recent quarters, we saw higher retention levels, continued rate increases and new business.
GAAP book value per share at year end was $70.12, up 8% for the year. Our capital position remains very strong, and we just completed our existing share repurchase program. 
Today we announced a new $1.3 billion buyback program. As you saw in our press release, we have provided 2015 operating income per share guidance of $7.35 to $7.65. And Rick will have more to say about guidance as well as our capital management activities.
And now Dino will provide detail on Commercial and Specialty lines, and then Paul will discuss Personal lines and claims.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. In a marketplace that was competitive but still behaving rationally regarding price and terms and condition, Commercial and Specialty both had strong performance in the fourth quarter. This was characterized most importantly, by excellent un
componenttext:
Thanks, John. In a marketplace that was competitive but still behaving rationally regarding price and terms and condition, Commercial and Specialty both had strong performance in the fourth quarter. This was characterized most importantly, by excellent underwriting profitability and by executing our stated plans of emphasizing the retention of our profitable portfolio, while pushing for rate increases on those accounts that still require it. We also leveraged our distinct underwriting and claims advantages to write new business in our targeted niches.
Beginning with CCI. The fourth quarter combined ratio was 88.5% compared to 89% in the fourth quarter of 2013 and 89.5% in the third quarter of 2014. The fourth quarter impact of catastrophe losses accounted for 1.8 points of the combined ratio in 2014 and 0.6 points in 2013. Excluding the impact of catastrophes, CCIs fourth quarter combined ratio improved to 86.7% into 2014 from 88.4% in the prior year.
Drilling down into the CCI lines, we had another strong performance in the Multiple Peril, where the combined ratio was 85.4% compared to the unusually low 73.5% in the fourth quarter of 2013. The Casualty combined ratio for the fourth quarter of 2014 was 99.8% compared to the 102.9% we posted in the fourth quarter of 2013. Our Workers' Compensation combined ratio of 80.2% was outstanding, more than an 11-point improvement over the 91.5% that we posted in the fourth quarter of 2013 and well below our 10-year average of 88%.
Property and Marine produced a fourth quarter combined ratio of 84.4% compared to 83.1% in the year-ago quarter. In recent conference calls, we told you that in light of rate increases over the past several years, we were increasingly focused on retention while at the same time, taking advantage of better priced new business in market segments we target. This focus is contributing to our positive growth. 
In CCI, fourth quarter net written premiums grew to 5% to $1.3 billion. Workers' Comp grew asked the percent. But as you would see if you look back at the results in previous quarters, this line can fluctuate substantially from quarter-to-quarter due to the presence or absence of a larger premium account. For example, our Workers' Comp growth rate for the third quarter of 2014 was down 1%, while for the full year, we grew the line by 6%, a little less in the 8% we grew it in 2013. 
Notwithstanding the fluctuation, we were able to achieve several points better retention in the fourth quarter versus the third quarter, along with a slight increase in rate, and we were able to cross-sell a few large policies to existing customer. 
Overall, retention for CCI in the fourth quarter was 88% in the U.S., high by historical standards and a 1-point improvement over the third quarter. Please note that in our press release, the retention and renewal rate changes for CCI and CSI that are stated to be for our third quarter are in fact are those for our fourth quarter. We apologize for any inconvenience. A corrected release is in the process of being issued.
Now even with this higher retention, we achieved an overall written renewal rate increase of 2% for the U.S. book. This was the 16th consecutive quarter we obtained rate increases and the earned premium impact continues to keep pace with our long-term loss cost trends. 
Outside the US, CCI's average renewal rate increases in the fourth quarter were marginally positive. As we noted last quarter, this successful execution of our rate retention strategy resulted in there being fewer accounts in our portfolio that need substantial rate increases or that needs to be called from the book entirely. Of course, in those instances, where we cannot secure appropriate rates and terms, the calling will persist. 
For prospective new business, we continue to take advantage of our unique expertise and products and services that target the market segments in which we specialize. In the fourth quarter, we were able to secure new business opportunities that we believe will meet our required return target in many of these segments. In the U.S., our new-to-lost business ratio was 1.4:1 compared to 1.0:1 in the third quarter of 2014. This improvement reflects the historically high retention rate and some additional new business.
Notwithstanding the continued improvement, new business writings as a percentage of our overall portfolio were still slightly below levels we were writing several years ago. For the full year, CCI's net written premiums increased 2% to $5.4 billion. The combined ratio was 89.9% in 2014 versus 86.5% in 2013. The impact of catastrophes accounted for 3.8 points of the 2014 combined ratio compared to 2.1 points in 2013. Excluding the impact of tax, CCI's combined ratio for the year was 86.1% in 2014 and 84.4% in 2013.
Turning now to Chubb Specialty Insurance. Our fourth quarter combined ratio was an outstanding 76.7% in 2014 and represented a 5-point improvement compared to 81.9% in the fourth quarter of 2013. And Professional Liability, which represents the majority of our portfolio, the combined ratio was 80.3% compared to 85.9% in the fourth quarter of 2013 due mainly to a higher level of favorable development. Our continued strong underwriting result in the quarter stemmed from our disciplined underwriting, which is increasingly informed by our use of advanced analytics, continued calling actions where we don't believe we can achieve our required return and accumulative effects of rate increases, which on our U.S. book exceeded 20% over the last 3 years.
With respect to growth, CCI's net written premiums in the fourth quarter were $701 million, down about 1%. For the Professional Liability portion of CSI, net written premiums of $628 million were essentially flat on a worldwide basis but up 3% in the U.S. As we have noted in the past, premium growth in Chubb Specialty can vary from quarter-to-quarter in part due to the absence or presence of large premium accounts, and in the fourth quarter, with simply fewer good business opportunities outside the U.S. than we did in the third quarter.
In the fourth quarter, renewal retention for Professional Liability the U.S. remained at a very high 89% level achieved in the third quarter. At the same time, we secured a 4% average renewal rate increase in our U.S. book in line with our long-term loss cost trend. The fourth quarter was the 13th consecutive quarter in which we achieved rate increases in the U.S.
In markets outside the U.S., the average renewal rate change was close to flat. In the U.S., Professional Liability's new-to-lost ratio in the fourth quarter was 1.3:1, unchanged from the third quarter. This was a function of high retention levels in both quarters and our ability to find quality new business opportunities in our target markets following several years of industry rate increases and underwriting actions.
Turning now to the Surety portion of the Specialty book. The combined ratio of 48.6% in the fourth quarter represented a 5-point improvement over the fourth quarter of 2013 and a 6-point improvement when compared to the third quarter of 2014. Net written premiums for Surety were $73 million, down 6%, reflecting the lack of large premium transactions like those booked in the fourth quarter of 2013 for our customers who were performing work on major construction projects. It is not uncommon to experience this variation in work orders, but with the U.S. economy improving, we expect that our Surety customers, who are among the best in their field, should particularly benefit from that growth.
For the full year 2014, CSI's net written premiums increased 2% to $2.7 billion, and the combined ratio was an outstanding 80.5% compared to 84.3% in 2013. Professional Liability premiums increased 3% to $2.4 billion and the combined ratio was 82.2% versus 89.3% in 2013. Surety premiums for 2014 declined 4% to $300 million and the combined ratio was 67.3% versus 47.2% in 2013. Bottom line, we are very pleased with the strategies we implemented and the actions we have taken to improve the profitability of our Specialty business, and we are well positioned to continue to grow profitably over time.
And with that, I'll turn it over to Paul.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dino. Chubb Personal Insurance performed very well in the fourth quarter of 2014. CPI net written premiums increased a healthy 4% to $1.1 billion. CPI delivered a terrific combined ratio of 83.9% in the fourth quarter, which is in line with the 83
componenttext:
Thanks, Dino. Chubb Personal Insurance performed very well in the fourth quarter of 2014. CPI net written premiums increased a healthy 4% to $1.1 billion. CPI delivered a terrific combined ratio of 83.9% in the fourth quarter, which is in line with the 83.5% produced in the corresponding quarter of 2013. Catastrophes had only 0.1 percentage point impact on CPI's fourth quarter combined ratio compared to a 5.3 point impact in the fourth quarter of 2013. CPI's x cat combined ratio for the fourth quarter of 2014 was 83.8% versus 78.2% in the fourth quarter of 2013. 
Homeowners premiums increased 3% for the quarter. The Homeowners combined ratio was 76.5% compared to 75.8% in the corresponding quarter of 2013. Catastrophes had a 0.1 percentage point impact on the Homeowners combined ratio in the fourth quarter of 2014 compared to 8.5 percentage points in the corresponding quarter of 2013. Excluding catastrophes, the Homeowners combined ratio in the fourth quarter was 76.4% versus 67.3% in the fourth quarter of 2013. As you might recall, we pointed out last year at this time that the 76.3% x cat combined ratio for Homeowners was unusually good result. The average Homeowners renewal premium increase total 6% in the U.S. compared to 7% in the third quarter.
In the fourth quarter, net written premiums for Personal Auto grew 4%. The Personal Auto combined ratio was 95.2% compared to 93.9% in the corresponding quarter of 2013. CPI policy retention in the U.S. in the fourth quarter of 2014 was 89% for both Homeowners and Personal Auto. Homeowners policy retention was down slightly while Personal Auto was unchanged from the third quarter of 2014.
In Other Personal, which includes our Accident, Personal Excess Liability and Yacht lines, we had strong growth of 6% in the fourth quarter of 2014 and the combined ratio was 95.1% compared to 96.8% in the corresponding quarter of 2013.
Looking now at our full year results, CPI's net written premiums increased 4% to $4.5 billion. CPI produced a combined ratio of 90.9% including 5.5 percentage points of catastrophe losses compared to a combined ratio of 87% for 2013, including a 7.2-point impact of catastrophes. Excluding catastrophes, CPI's combined ratio for the full year was 85.4% in 2014 versus 79.8% for 2013. 
For all of 2014, Homeowners premiums increased by 4% to $2.8 billion. The Homeowners combined ratio was 88.3% including an 8.9 percentage point impact from catastrophes. Compared to a combined ratio of 82.3% in 2013, including an 11.5-point impact from catastrophes. Excluding the impact of catastrophes, the Homeowners combined ratio for the full year was 79.4% in 2014 versus 70.8% in 2013. 
Personal Auto premiums increased 1% in 2014 to $740 million and the combined ratio was 96.8% compared to 94.8% in 2013. 
Other Personal lines premiums increased 8% for the full year to $1 billion and the combined ratio was 94% versus 94.8% in 2013. 
Turning now to claims for Chubb overall. It was a fairly benign quarter from a loss perspective. On an x cat basis, [indiscernible] claim counts increased only 3% from the fourth quarter of 2013, which is in line with our premium growth.
Regarding catastrophes, their impact in the fourth quarter of 2014 was 0.8 percentage points of the combined ratio or $25 million before tax. This includes $35 million of favorable development from cat events earlier in 2014, which was partially offset by $11 million of unfavorable development from cat events in 2013 and prior years.
Losses from catastrophe events that occurred in the fourth quarter 2014 totaled $49 million and were dominated by 2 hail and windstorms, one in Brisbane, Australia and then another that impacted Texas and Kansas. The impact of catastrophes for the full year 2014 was 3.6 percentage points or $444 million before tax, reflecting $11 million of unfavorable development from events that occurred in 2013 and prior years.
And now I will turn it over to Ricky, who will review our financial results in more detail.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Paul. Looking first at our operating results. We had strong underwriting income of $477 million in the quarter. For the full year, underwriting income was $1.4 billion. Our combined ratio for the fourth quarter was 84.3% compared to 85.5% in the s
componenttext:
Thanks, Paul. Looking first at our operating results. We had strong underwriting income of $477 million in the quarter. For the full year, underwriting income was $1.4 billion. Our combined ratio for the fourth quarter was 84.3% compared to 85.5% in the same quarter a year earlier. Our expense ratio for the quarter was 30.5% in 2014 versus 30.8% in 2013. For the full year, our combined ratio was 88.3% in 2014 compared to 86.1% in 2013, and our expense ratio for the full year was 31.4% in 2014 and 31.9% in 2013. Please note that over the past few years, our expense ratio in the fourth quarter has been lower than for other quarters in the full year due to seasonality. The expense ratio varies from quarter-to-quarter due to mix of business and other variables.
Property & Casualty investment income after-tax was down 6% in the fourth quarter to $267 million, due once again to lower reinvestment rates in our fixed maturity portfolios and to a lesser extent, the impact of foreign currency translation. 
Net income was higher than operating income in the quarter due to net realized investment gains before tax of $18 million or $0.06 per share after-tax, including a $0.01 per share loss from alternative investments. For comparison, in the fourth quarter of 2013, we had net realized investment gains before tax of $67 million or $0.17 per share after-tax, including a gain of $0.09 per share from alternative investment.
Unrealized depreciation before tax at December 31, 2014 was $2.7 billion. For comparison at year end 2013, unrealized depreciation before tax was $1.9 billion. The increase in unrealized depreciation in 2014 largely reflects the decrease in interest rate and the increase in equity market that occurred during the year. The total carrying value of our consolidated investment portfolio was $43.5 billion as of December 31, 2014. The composition of our portfolio remains largely unchanged from the prior quarter. The average duration of our fixed maturity portfolio is 4 years and the average credit rating is AA3.
We continue to have excellent liquidity at the holding company. At December 31, our holding company portfolio had $1.8 billion of investments, including approximately $585 million of short-term investments. Book value per share under GAAP at December 31, 2014 was $70.12 compared to $64.83 at year end 2013, an increase of 8%. Adjusted book value per share, which we calculate with available-for-sale fixed maturities at amortized cost, was $65.03 compared to $61.86 at 2013 year end and increase of 5%.
With regard to book value, as you may know, companies like Chubb that have defined benefit pension and postretirement benefit plan are required to prepare an annual revaluation of the plan's assets can benefit liabilities. As a result of our revaluation at the end of 2014, the estimate of our plan viability increased and our change in book value for the fourth quarter was adversely impacted by approximately $350 million after tax. 
The increase in our plan's liabilities was primarily due to the decrease in our discount rate assumption that resulted from the decrease in interest rates at December 31, 2014 compared to the prior year-end rate and to a lesser extent, a change in our mortality assumption. The change in our mortality assumption reflects the impact of the October 2014 revision of the Society of Actuaries mortality tables, which many companies, including Chubb, take into account the measurement of their benefit plan liabilities.
In addition, the change in book value during the quarter was negatively affected by that $75 million due to the impact of foreign currency translation. 
As for loss reserves, we estimate that we had favorable development in the fourth quarter of 2014 on prior year reserves by SBU, as follows: In CPI, we had about $15 million, CCI had about $50 million, CSI had about $90 million and the runoff reinsurance assumed business had none, bringing our total favorable development to about $155 million for the quarter. This represents a favorable impact on the fourth quarter combined ratio of 5 points overall, including an adverse impact from prior year catastrophes of $11 million. 
For comparison, in the fourth quarter of 2013, we had about $115 million of favorable development for the company overall, including $25 million in CPI, $35 million in CCI, $55 million in CSI, and none in reinsurance assumed. The favorable impact on the combined ratio in the fourth quarter of 2013 was about 4 points overall, including a favorable impact from prior-year catastrophes of $6 million.
Favorable development for the full year 2014 totaled about $635 million and had a favorable impact on the combined ratio of approximately 5 points, compared to $710 million in 2013 and a favorable impact on the combined ratio of approximately 6 points.
For the fourth quarter of 2014, our x cat accident year combined ratio was 88.8% compared to 87% in last year's fourth quarter. And for the full year 2014, our x cat accident year combined ratio was 90% compared to 88.4% in 2013.
During the fourth quarter of 2014, our loss reserves decreased by $350 million, including a decrease of $344 million for the insurance business and a decrease of $6 million for the reinsurance assumed business, which is in runoff. The overall decrease in reserves reflects the decrease of $53 million related to catastrophes. The impact of currency translation on loss reserves during the quarter resulted in a decrease in reserves of about $155 million.
Turning now to capital management. During the fourth quarter, we repurchased approximately 3.4 million shares at an aggregate cost of $346 million. The average cost of our repurchases in the quarter was $100.58 per share. For the full year 2014, we repurchased 16.9 million shares at an aggregate cost of $1.6 billion and an average cost of $92.05 per share. As of December 31, 2014, there was approximately $52 million remaining under our January 2014 repurchase program, which we completed this month.
As we announced today, our Board of Directors have authorized a new $1.3 billion share repurchase program. The size of the share buyback program is essentially in line with the 2015 operating income reflected in our guidance less shareholder dividend. We intend to complete this program by the end of January 2016, subject to market condition and other factors.
Finally, let me make a few additional comments regarding our guidance. We expect operating income per share for 2015 to be in the range of $7.35 to $7.65 with a midpoint of $7.50.
Before reviewing the key assumptions underlying our 2015 operating income per share guidance, I would like to highlight a couple of external factors that will impact our financial results this year. First, interest rates have continued to decline on a global basis, which will once again, put pressure on investment income. In addition, the impact of lower interest rates on our discount assumption will increase our pension and post-retirement benefits cost in 2015, which will be reflected in slightly higher expense ratio for the full year compared to the 31.4% expense ratio in 2014. 
Second, since roughly 1/4 of our business is generated outside the United States, the recent strengthening of the U.S. dollar against most major currencies will have a negative impact on both a premium growth and investment income. As we said in our press release, we are assuming for the full year a negative 2 percentage point impact of foreign currency translation on written premium growth and a negative 1 percentage point impact on the growth of Property & Casualty investment income after-tax.
Our operating income per share guidance assumes the full year 2015, an increase of 1% to 3% in net written premium or 3% to 5% excluding the negative impact of foreign currency translation, a combined ratio of 89% to 90%, a decline of 6% to 8% in Property & Casualty investment income after taxes or 5% to 7% -- down 5% to 7% excluding the negative impact of foreign currency translation. And our guidance assumes $230 million average diluted shares outstanding. Our guidance also assumes 4 percentage points of catastrophe losses in line with our median and annual catastrophe impact over the last 10 years. In terms of sensitivity, the impact of each percentage point of catastrophe losses on 2015 operating income per share is approximately $0.36.
And now I will turn it back to John.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ricky. Chubb had an excellent fourth quarter, posting record operating income per share of $2.29. We generate annualized GAAP ROE of 13.6% and annualized operating ROE of 14.8%. The fourth quarter results capped off a terrific year in which we ach
componenttext:
Thanks, Ricky. Chubb had an excellent fourth quarter, posting record operating income per share of $2.29. We generate annualized GAAP ROE of 13.6% and annualized operating ROE of 14.8%. The fourth quarter results capped off a terrific year in which we achieved excellent operating and net income per share. Renewal rates improved in all 3 SBUs with average U.S. rate increases for the full year of 3% for Standard Commercial, 5% for Professional Liability and we also achieved average U.S. renewal increases of 6% for Personal lines.
The growing rate adequacy of our overall book has increased our focus on retaining more of our profitable portfolio, as evidenced by our higher renewal retention rates. In the light of broader industry rate increases in the last few years, we're able to secure some additional new business that was attractively priced within the market segment we target.
We continued to actively manage our capital in 2014 by returning more than $2 billion to our shareholders through a combination of share repurchases and dividends. Our ongoing commitment to capital management is demonstrated by the new $1.3 billion share repurchase program we announced today.
As you can tell from our 2015 guidance, we're expecting another overall strong year despite the dual headwinds of continued low interest rates and the strong dollar.
And with that, I'll open the lines to your questions.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take your first question from Amit Kumar with Macquarie.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take your first question from Amit Kumar with Macquarie.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Two quick questions on the guidance. The first is on the NPW  guidance of 1% to 3%. And even if I exclude the foreign exchange impact and factoring the comments on retentions, why wouldn't the top line move directionally in the opposite direction more ver
componenttext: Two quick questions on the guidance. The first is on the NPW  guidance of 1% to 3%. And even if I exclude the foreign exchange impact and factoring the comments on retentions, why wouldn't the top line move directionally in the opposite direction more versus what we have seen previously? Is it simply a function of new business? Or are you factoring in some maybe recruitment [ph] going forward?

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's the combination of things. Yes. I'll start by putting our 2014 premium growth in perspective. So for the full year 2014, net premiums written increased 3% or 4% excluding the effect of foreign currency translation. So we're expecting ne
componenttext: Well, I think it's the combination of things. Yes. I'll start by putting our 2014 premium growth in perspective. So for the full year 2014, net premiums written increased 3% or 4% excluding the effect of foreign currency translation. So we're expecting next year that x currency premium grow will be consistent with our 2014 growth, and we believe that it's reasonable based on the current market environment. In terms of assumptions, I'm not -- I can't go through each of the industry [ph] pieces, but obviously, retention is strong. You heard the commentary on rates of what we're seeing in the near term. And then there's some new business, of course, as well. And I'd highlight also, if you think about the relationship between growth, premium growth and renewal rate increases, they're not necessarily correlated. So for example, if you look back in 2013, we actually have lower x currency premium growth of 3%. But average renewal rates were actually higher than they were in 2014. I hope that gives you some idea of what we're thinking.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. The only other question I had was on the discussion on the combined ratio guidance. Can you -- the x cat guidance is 85% to 86%. Can you talk about how you're thinking about the underlying accident the year going forward? Does that still i
componenttext: That's helpful. The only other question I had was on the discussion on the combined ratio guidance. Can you -- the x cat guidance is 85% to 86%. Can you talk about how you're thinking about the underlying accident the year going forward? Does that still improve based on how on earn rates come and exceeding loss cost trends? Or does it sort of flat line? Can you just expand on that?

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think -- It's John. I mean, a variety of things can happen, obviously. It depends on some degree where rates do go. But when you look at the 2015 accident year, let's start with what most of the analysts talk about as margin expansion, meaning the
componenttext: Well, I think -- It's John. I mean, a variety of things can happen, obviously. It depends on some degree where rates do go. But when you look at the 2015 accident year, let's start with what most of the analysts talk about as margin expansion, meaning the earn rate versus long-term loss cost trends. Remember that the 2015 accident year is based on earn rate, which means it's 50% driven by rate increases in year 2014 and 50% by rate increases in the year 2015. In the year 2014, our rate increases exceeded loss cost trends and even our shorter-term loss cost. So we're going with some headwind, 1 point or 2, from 2014, plus 50% of 2015 accident year. Tailwind, not a headwind -- tailwind. No wonder why I can't fly a plane. Now as we move in towards 2015, right now, our earn rate is still a little bit in excess of our loss cost trends in the fourth quarter, but our written rate is about neutral to loss cost trends. I don't know where rate is going, but I expect as we run a variety of scenarios, it's more biased than the scenarios to rate increases not being as high as they currently are. But there could be some pressure on margins related to the 50% of accident year performance related to 2015. But then you've got to combine that with the 2014 tailwind, and it's hard to call whether you're going to have to see overall for the 2015 accident year contraction or margin expansion. Then the second thing is that, we've talked about this [indiscernible] in the past is that margin expansion analysis, even if correct, doesn't necessarily correlate to the year-over-year movement and combined ratios. The other big factor is how the actual losses compare to loss cost trends. And as we saw this year, our actual losses were, especially in the Property line, or I'd say Homeowners, were significantly higher than what we've experienced in recent years. And we'd hope to see some reversion to the mean in that line of business. Now there's no guarantee that you can't be higher than the mean 2 years in a row. So we're conservative when we look at that. But again, we're hoping for some reversions to the mean than actual losses. In some of the lines, we had unfavorable experience in this year, which were largely related to a lot of factors such as fire and non-cat weather.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And if I can add one thing, Mark, from the loss ratio side. As I mentioned in my remarks on the expense ratio side, given the higher pension cost that we expect to incur in 2015, that the expense ratio also will be higher than what we experienced in 2014.
componenttext: And if I can add one thing, Mark, from the loss ratio side. As I mentioned in my remarks on the expense ratio side, given the higher pension cost that we expect to incur in 2015, that the expense ratio also will be higher than what we experienced in 2014.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And finally, when you're looking at our guidance, you asked specifically about accident year. But when you look at our guidance for combined ratio, that obviously, is a calendar year number. The big missing factor is development, and development is a majo
componenttext: And finally, when you're looking at our guidance, you asked specifically about accident year. But when you look at our guidance for combined ratio, that obviously, is a calendar year number. The big missing factor is development, and development is a major contributing result. It was 5 points this year. I don't know if you can run that forever, so we have a variety of scenarios about development. But you'd have to take that into account when you formulate your own projections.

componenttext: Sure, Jay. It's Dino. Yes, the Casualty combined ratio was 99.8% in the fourth quarter, when you compare it to the third quarter of 2014, which is 95.3%. That was 102.9% in the fourth quarter of '13. The primary reason for the deterioration relative to the third quarter of 2014's impact of asbestos and environmental claims, which was heavier in the fourth quarter, although partially offset by more favorable development in Excess Liability. One other thing to point out, if you look at the full year 2014, our Casualty combined ratio was 92.5%. It was a 5-point improvement over 2013. So we remain pleased with the progress of the improvement in this line of business.

componenttextpreview: Okay. That's notable. All right. Then my second and unrelated question is on the high net worth, Personal lines business, which Chubb has a major presence. Ace announced it's buying the Fireman's Fund high net worth business. I'd be interested in your tho
componenttext: Okay. That's notable. All right. Then my second and unrelated question is on the high net worth, Personal lines business, which Chubb has a major presence. Ace announced it's buying the Fireman's Fund high net worth business. I'd be interested in your thoughts in terms of what that means for the competitive dynamic for a pretty important market for Chubb.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Jay, this is Paul. Obviously, we don't know for certain how or if this will impact us. But over the decade, I think you all know there's been several firms, which  have entered the high net worth space to compete against us. Obviously, some of those playe
componenttext: Jay, this is Paul. Obviously, we don't know for certain how or if this will impact us. But over the decade, I think you all know there's been several firms, which  have entered the high net worth space to compete against us. Obviously, some of those players have exited over the years as well. We kind of look at it this way. We were the pioneers in this market. We developed it in the beginning. We are successfully competing in it now for nearly 3 decades and that we have every intention of doing so going forward.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So no real shift anticipated as a result of that acquisition?
componenttext: Okay. So no real shift anticipated as a result of that acquisition?

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015

componenttext: Your next question comes from Vinay Misquith with Evercore ISI.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: The first question is on lost trend. I believe you mentioned in your comments that you said written rate was in line with loss trend. So I'm just curious as to what you're assuming for loss trend.
componenttext: The first question is on lost trend. I believe you mentioned in your comments that you said written rate was in line with loss trend. So I'm just curious as to what you're assuming for loss trend.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me talk about that a second and let's -- and I'll reiterate something I said last quarter. When we talk about loss trend, we use 4%, but let me define that for you. Our loss trend is largely macroeconomic factors such as in Workers' Comp and heal
componenttext: Yes, let me talk about that a second and let's -- and I'll reiterate something I said last quarter. When we talk about loss trend, we use 4%, but let me define that for you. Our loss trend is largely macroeconomic factors such as in Workers' Comp and healthcare inflation. Loss cost trends are used by different firms in different ways. What it doesn't take into account is the impact of proactive underwriting initiatives. So the kind of calling of the book we've been talking about doing over the past 2 years reduces our loss cost in the short term. When you take into account the underwriting initiatives we have underway, we'd expect our short-term loss cost trends to be about 1 point or 2 lower than long-term loss cost trends. So when we budget and look at profitability, we do this granularly by line, but we'd probably look at our short-term loss cost trends at 2 to 3 points rather than the 4-point long term loss cost trend. But when we compare it -- when I say we're about even in the fourth quarter, I was comparing written to long-term. We're still 1 point or so above what we envisioned to be the short-term loss cost trends.

componenttext: Year-over-year? Yes, well it was all due to CPI. Last year, we had an unusually good quarter. This year, we had a decent quarter. There was about an 8-point deterioration at Homeowners. And that was -- basically, it was all attributable to somewhat higher-than-normal non-cat and fire losses in the fourth quarter this year and extremely low fire losses in non-cat weather in the fourth quarter of last year. The rest of the unit, CCI and CSI, were pretty much flat.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Josh Stirling with Sanford Bernstein.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Josh Stirling with Sanford Bernstein.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wonder if I can follow on with a question on your Personal lines business. I think I noticed you guys started advertising on television recently, and I was kind of surprised to see that. I mean, just you're an agency company. You've got a long standing
componenttext: I wonder if I can follow on with a question on your Personal lines business. I think I noticed you guys started advertising on television recently, and I was kind of surprised to see that. I mean, just you're an agency company. You've got a long standing brand. And I'm wondering how this kind of fits with your positioning of the Personal lines business, how you are looking to be competitive as that business presumably gets more competitive. And can we read this into you guys thinking like somehow, like you've been measuring the brand value or consumer awareness and we've been seeing it slipping? Or is this, I mean, sort of just something you guys felt like it would be nice to do?

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Josh, this is Paul. First of all, thanks for noticing the ad. So No Regrets is the theme of the ad, and it pretty much tags on to what we had in the past about expect the unexpected and insurance doesn't matter till it matters and that kind of a thing. It
componenttext: Josh, this is Paul. First of all, thanks for noticing the ad. So No Regrets is the theme of the ad, and it pretty much tags on to what we had in the past about expect the unexpected and insurance doesn't matter till it matters and that kind of a thing. It's not just a Personal lines ad. It is a Chubb's corporate ad. So we have people in there from a business, we have a couple of Personal lines customers. It's really just trying to make certain that our names is out there in the marketplace. We do see, though, that there were some customers that during the economic downturn, whether they be in the Commercial or Personal, that decided to save some money by going to less expensive insurance. And now that the economy is improving, we want to make certain that they know we're still out here and they don't have any regrets when they come to us. So that's really what it's all about. We're getting great feedback, though, from our agents and a number of customers who called up and said it's a nice use of a little bit of humor. So we're excited about it.

componenttext: So listen, I wonder if I could ask just another question. We spend a lot of time talking about your [indiscernible] segments, but I was -- I just sort of looked into the numbers and maybe realized that the international business, I mean, it looks like it hasn't -- I mean, I know FX makes this more complicated and harder to do with the way you present your numbers. But it doesn't look like it's had that much growth, but it also seems to have lower margins than your franchise in the United States. And I'm kind of wondering what you think your priorities are for those businesses? And do have opportunities to accelerate the growth rates or alternatively to drive some greater profitabilities so they could look more like the United States?

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, let me say it. When we look at that, we discuss it as items, so we discussed this currently at the board level overseas business and growth. It's very hard. You mentioned one thing. You know you have exchange in here, so it's very hard to look at. I t
componenttext: No, let me say it. When we look at that, we discuss it as items, so we discussed this currently at the board level overseas business and growth. It's very hard. You mentioned one thing. You know you have exchange in here, so it's very hard to look at. I think we -- overseas, it used to be 25% or 26%. We think that maybe it's 23% or so today. But exchange is a big driver in that. And the other driver of relative growth is rates, and rates in the U.S. over the last 3 years, have been significantly higher than rates overseas. Overseas, the growth has been hurt overseas by rates directly and also because of the lack of increase in the rates has made new opportunities less attractive. We still look at overseas as an area which should grow somewhat better than the U.S., constant exchange and similar rate increases. But we've also suffered over the last for years of an economic downturn in Europe from Brazil turning down. So there were a lot of things that happened in the last few years in the overseas economy in general to exchange rates and then the insurance industry, just. Rate increases have not been as attractive as they've been in the U.S.

componenttext: Right. And then, I guess, just looking in Commercial overall and then taking into consideration, some of the non-cat weather, I felt like that was more in CPI during 2014. It looks like the underlying loss ratio didn't really change all that much, but you've got rate throughout the year in CCI. And it seems like composite [ph] probably a bigger part of that growth and maybe got more rate than the rest of the book. Just trying to square that. Should we see that? Was it the non-cat losses that maybe masked some of that margin expansion? Or should we see some of that start to trickle through next year?

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't -- we don't -- we pointed out in the second quarter, we had some very high, large losses in the second quarter. They weren't non-cat weather necessarily. But for the full year, our Property and Marine kind of ran in line with our 5-year average, s
componenttext: I don't -- we don't -- we pointed out in the second quarter, we had some very high, large losses in the second quarter. They weren't non-cat weather necessarily. But for the full year, our Property and Marine kind of ran in line with our 5-year average, so I don't think that was an issue. I'd say this. First of all, when you look at CCI, I mean, we basically went from, what, 5, 4, 3 and 2 were our rate increases over the course of the year. So really, we didn't -- we really didn't exceed long-term loss cost trends by any significant amount, if at all, over the course of the year. Then secondly, as these [ph] anomalies and actual versus loss trends. For a point, we're talking about, 2013 was a very good year. So if you look at the analysis, 2013, 2014 in an accident year basis, just on margin expansion, maybe you should have been a point better off, a point gets lost in the ground [ph]. 2013 was a good starting base. So nothing really there to see.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015

componenttext: Okay, got it. And then just last, on the Other Personal Lines business, so that -- so as you're running, it's been running consistently in that sort of mid-90s range. Is that -- and it's been growing more than the others. So like, how are you thinking about that? Is that -- I mean, is it low hanging fruit just from a bundling perspective? Does it provide retention benefits that more than offset the fact that the profitability is less than some of the other lines of business that you're -- I mean, growing as fast? Or is it the accident business that's not anywhere near the bundling of the Other Personal Lines business? Just trying to get some context there.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: No problem, Mike. It's Paul again. Just shy about 70% of our Other Personal business made up of accident, and accident has been the -- what's helping the growth -- fuel the growth in the Other Personal category there. It gets a little bit lumpy, you're ri
componenttext: No problem, Mike. It's Paul again. Just shy about 70% of our Other Personal business made up of accident, and accident has been the -- what's helping the growth -- fuel the growth in the Other Personal category there. It gets a little bit lumpy, you're right, when you look at it, basically running in the high single digits for the year. The absence or presence of a large accident program, [indiscernible] is pretty much what will drive and make some of the swings there. But we hired some people a couple of years back, and we're doing very well in the accident space. Obviously, we're doing very well also in the Personal Excess Liability space. We've been writing a lot more umbrellas on individuals as well as on groups. The Yacht business is slowly coming out of the doldrums from the economic downturn, and that's really what's going in that category.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I'd say that accident, obviously being the lion share of the category. I mean, it's a growth business, so right now, the combines aren't exactly where we want us to be, which is quite often the case when you have a growth business. If your overall p
componenttext: Well, I'd say that accident, obviously being the lion share of the category. I mean, it's a growth business, so right now, the combines aren't exactly where we want us to be, which is quite often the case when you have a growth business. If your overall performance in that category 95% and that's going to help us 70%, you can conclude that [indiscernible] the help us not running significantly below that. We hope over the shorter term that we actually see its substantial improvement in accident health. But we're not unhappy. We're getting of growth, and with growth come a little bit higher expenses. And [indiscernible] income as fast. So over time, hopefully, not too far, not too much time, it will improve.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just first question, if you look back on 2013 and 2014, your operating result is pretty strong. You have record earnings. But ROE stay roughly around between anywhere 11% to 13%. Going forward, and to the combined ratio potentially could deteriorate becau
componenttext: Just first question, if you look back on 2013 and 2014, your operating result is pretty strong. You have record earnings. But ROE stay roughly around between anywhere 11% to 13%. Going forward, and to the combined ratio potentially could deteriorate because the pricing is no longer rising as fast as in the past 2 years. And you may seem continue to be under pressure. And all you can do actually, return, that's great, return 100% of earnings to shareholders. Is there anything you can do to improve their -- to improve that ROE or that's what we're looking at for the next few years?

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, obviously, we're doing a number of things. One, you've heard on the business side and on this call and others, some of the underwriting actions we've been taking to try to continue to improve the profitability of some of the corporate business, wher
componenttext: Well, obviously, we're doing a number of things. One, you've heard on the business side and on this call and others, some of the underwriting actions we've been taking to try to continue to improve the profitability of some of the corporate business, where maybe they're not performing at the level where we want. On the investment income side, I can tell you unequivocally, we are not going to change our investment strategy. We are not going to reach for yield in this environment. We specifically do not see those opportunities, so the way we're going to try to continue to grow the earnings line as well as especially ROE is continue to do what we've been doing. We'll continue to be active in managing our capital. And there really aren't a whole lot of silver bullets out there. In environment where we are today, where interest rates are, we think the ROEs that we are generating are actually quite attractive. And our target ROE of 10% plus inflation over time has not changed. It's still what we're pushing in our pricing and in our rate discussions. And so the reality is the only way you can get better than that, you've got -- with investment income where it is, you've got to get a better loss ratio. So we continue to push on that.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we're talking 12.5% to 14.5% over the last 2 years return of equity in a 1% or 2% interest rate environment. I mean, that's a reasonably good return on equity when your investment income goes down 5% or 6% a year. And we're also carrying around, we th
componenttext: And we're talking 12.5% to 14.5% over the last 2 years return of equity in a 1% or 2% interest rate environment. I mean, that's a reasonably good return on equity when your investment income goes down 5% or 6% a year. And we're also carrying around, we think, strong excess capital position. So I think those are pretty good returns. That's all -- it's hard we gave you guidance for next year and what we expect in earnings so you can come up with some sort of assessment of where our ROE will be. But in this environment, it's interest rate environment. It's investment income environment. You're not going to be running 16%, 17% and 18% return on equity.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015

componenttext: This is Paul, Kai. This approach is really focused on providing a price comparison-driven distribution option for potential customers. I think it's really too early to know based on our experience if these types of distribution platforms actually work or not. I think I would directly to look what's happening in the U.K. in the last couple of years. There's been a couple of those platforms operating there. And what I can tell you is they've had little to no impact on our automobile writings in the United Kingdom.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: As of now, we have an insignificant number of claims reported, and our initial investigations have not revealed any very large claims. But I want to just put a little word of caution there. It isn't unusual with a Juno-type snowstorm to have customers rep
componenttext: As of now, we have an insignificant number of claims reported, and our initial investigations have not revealed any very large claims. But I want to just put a little word of caution there. It isn't unusual with a Juno-type snowstorm to have customers report claims to us over a period of weeks. A water stain will appear in the closet they hadn't opened up for a few weeks or they'll get to their secondary home and inspect it and see that there's been some damage there. So we're really encouraged by the quality of claim activity that we've had to date. But we're going have to continue to monitor this. It's just too early to tell.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Ricky, I'd like to know how you think about forecasting investment yield decline or investment -- to the extent of which the last 3 months of interest rates have come into that. What percent of the portfolio comes up for reinvestment during the year? It l
componenttext: Ricky, I'd like to know how you think about forecasting investment yield decline or investment -- to the extent of which the last 3 months of interest rates have come into that. What percent of the portfolio comes up for reinvestment during the year? It looks like your forecast accelerated or accelerated in terms of declines from where it was a year ago. What are the ingredients that make that happen?

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: You touched on a lot of them. So obviously, the way we do the forecasting is we take a look at the maturity profile of our portfolio in the upcoming year. We have to make, obviously, some assumptions related to what our cash flow is going to look like. We
componenttext: You touched on a lot of them. So obviously, the way we do the forecasting is we take a look at the maturity profile of our portfolio in the upcoming year. We have to make, obviously, some assumptions related to what our cash flow is going to look like. We have our buy back and other things that impact all that. And we buy securities over time, which can impact the sort of the maturities and when they actually occur. And we start by looking at that. We have an estimate and a projection, if you will, of what we think our cash flows are going to look like with the maturities. We have an estimate of what we think reinvestment rates are going to look like, and we project down over time. Then obviously, as I mentioned, we also, this time around, given what's happening in the currency market, also needed to take a look at what we're seeing both in the U.S. and outside the U.S. to make some guesstimate about what we think the impact of currency will be. So that's how we do it. We look at our actual maturities and project down. It's sort of a moving target because things change over time. But we have a pretty good idea of what we think the maturity schedule is going to look like. And as you know, we actually published a maturity schedule in our 10-K every year, where we highlight the next few years of what the expected maturities are. So you can get a pretty good deal from that.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015

componenttext: And interest rates have deteriorated in the recent month, and the dollar has gotten stronger. So the outlook has deteriorated from real world factors. Was that permanent?

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Is it reasonable to look at what's happened to the 10-year in the last 6 months and say the degree of the move is similar to the new money yield change at Chubb?
componenttext: Is it reasonable to look at what's happened to the 10-year in the last 6 months and say the degree of the move is similar to the new money yield change at Chubb?

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't have the comparison of what the new money yields were at year end last year. I can tell you what our current new money rates are and maybe you'll get a sense from that. But basically, where we reinvesting today and, obviously, as I've said this be
componenttext: I don't have the comparison of what the new money yields were at year end last year. I can tell you what our current new money rates are and maybe you'll get a sense from that. But basically, where we reinvesting today and, obviously, as I've said this before, depends on asset class, but they're all actually pretty -- they [indiscernible] pretty close together these days. So outside the U.S., I'd say, our current reinvestment rates are about 2.25%. Our reinvestment rates in tax exempt in the U.S. is probably about 2.4% or thereabouts. And our reinvestment rate for our tax book securities in the U.S. is probably around 2.5%. And just to give -- I'll go one step further. So given that, I can try to at least give you some idea of when we think about the maturity schedule and what's maturing over the next, call it, few years on the U.S. tax exempt side, we're probably -- those reinvestment rates will probably be 175 to 200 basis points below our maturing book yields on average over the next few years. For our domestic taxable fixed income maturities, it's probably 75 to 125 basis points. And there is some variability in it because obviously, depending when you bought a security, if you bought something 5 years ago, it may have had a higher coupon at the financial crisis than this period, and that was going to be maturing. And then outside the U.S., it's 25 to 75 basis points.

componenttext: I was hoping to get a bit more color on the continued favorable development in Professional lines. I'm wondering if you can talk about what accident year this is coming from. And is driven more by the frequency of claims or the severity of claims that you're seeing?

componenttext: Well, let me say that -- your first question. Professional Liability reserve, the favorable development came from actually, it's 2010 and prior. '11 and '13 roughly flat, '12 slightly adverse. Obviously, the later years, you don't have as much development. componenttextpreview: Well, I think when you talk about development, you're talking about kind of largely claims that you -- such as you're going back in what, 3, 4, 5 years you know about. I mean, if you're talk about severity, I mean, you're not talking much about frequency.
componenttext: Well, I think when you talk about development, you're talking about kind of largely claims that you -- such as you're going back in what, 3, 4, 5 years you know about. I mean, if you're talk about severity, I mean, you're not talking much about frequency. In terms of frequency in current period, they look fine. But when we talk about development, you're talking about how largely about the severity on claims you know about. Obviously, there can be some you don't. But for most part, that's not the contributing factor. It's the loss experience on claims, if you have, and you know about.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Maybe, I'll throw a little bit if color in here. The claim trends, as John was saying, the pattern is very considerably depending on the lines business, the types of claims. For example, EPL claims historically have tended to have a shorter lifespan than,
componenttext: Maybe, I'll throw a little bit if color in here. The claim trends, as John was saying, the pattern is very considerably depending on the lines business, the types of claims. For example, EPL claims historically have tended to have a shorter lifespan than, say, public D&O claims. But with the economic downturn, we saw some lengthening in the duration of those EPL claims. While the notable segment of public D&O claims, those really involve in a merger and acquisition activity, tended to results faster than the other types of D&O claims.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So it is favorable loss experience largely related to severity on prior activities.
componenttext: So it is favorable loss experience largely related to severity on prior activities.

componenttext: I'd say it isn't about valuation of stock. It's certainly not stopping us from doing buybacks. componenttext: And from an -- and just one more point from an excess capital position, we continue to believe that we are in a very strong excess capital position based on or both our internal assessment as well as external. So the difference in the size of the buybacks year-over-year has nothing to do with that as well.

componenttext: Well, just because it's cheaper doesn't necessarily make it economic. I mean, it's cheaper than it was, but I mean we think we've balanced it pretty well. When we buy cat exposure, we've got cat reinsurance. That has a few factors in it. One is sort of our balance sheet position and what we're willing to subject it to. The second is economics. It's still not cheap. And no, I don't think you'll see us going out and adding ultra [ph] of cat reinsurance.

componenttext: But we are obviously, looking at the opportunities in the market. And on an opportunistic basis, we think that we can take advantage of the opportunities in the market either to promote our growth or manage our volatility, we will certainly think about that. But as I said, I think on the last quarter call, we're not going to change our long-standing strategy of focusing on underwriting and pricing of [indiscernible] because reinsurance may be a little bit cheaper.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Clearly, with the broadening appetite in capacity and some of the lower pricing that you're referring to, you're going to get individual situations where we're able now to get into an account that required larger limits of insurance than we would be
componenttext: Yes. Clearly, with the broadening appetite in capacity and some of the lower pricing that you're referring to, you're going to get individual situations where we're able now to get into an account that required larger limits of insurance than we would be comfortable with. So today's facultative reinsurance dynamics helps us support those larger limits while we still effectively manage our overall net exposure. Now occasionally, we've also used cat reinsurance where maybe one of our insurers has moved to an area and expanded the area where it -- they have -- there's too much catastrophe exposure there for us, and we can use some of the facultative reinsurance to cover us there. In this way, we've got to be able to keep that account. So on individual account level, we're clearly taking advantage of the facultative reinsurance marketplace. But as Ricky and John point out, we don't see it as any -- influencing, any wholesale change in our underwriting strategy.
