headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone and welcome to The Chubb Corporation's First Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded.Before we begin, Chubb has asked me to make the following statements: In order to help you understand Chubb, its indust
componenttext:
Good day, everyone and welcome to The Chubb Corporation's First Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded.
Before we begin, Chubb has asked me to make the following statements: In order to help you understand Chubb, its industries and its results, members of Chubb's management team will include in today's presentation forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. It is possible that actual results might differ from estimates and forecasts that Chubb's management team makes today. Additional information regarding factors that could cause such differences appears in Chubb's filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
In their prepared remarks and responses to questions during today's presentation, Chubb's management may refer to financial measures that are not derived from generally accepted accounting principles or GAAP. Reconciliations of these non-GAAP financial measures to the most direct comparable GAAP measures and related information are provided in a press release and financial supplement for the first quarter 2015, which are available on the Investors section of Chubb's website at www.chubb.com.
Please also note that no portion of this conference call may be reproduced or rebroadcast in any form without Chubb's prior written consent. Replays of this webcast will be available through Friday, May 22, 2015. Those listening after April 23, 2015, should please note that information and forecast provided in this recording will not necessarily be updated and it is possible that the information will no longer be current.
Now I will turn the call over to Mr. Finnegan.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you for joining us. As we said in our press release, Chubb produced solid financial results in the first quarter of 2015. These were achieve even with the adverse impact of both cat and non-cat weather-related losses, primarily in the homeowners lin
componenttext:
Thank you for joining us. As we said in our press release, Chubb produced solid financial results in the first quarter of 2015. These were achieve even with the adverse impact of both cat and non-cat weather-related losses, primarily in the homeowners line, spending from the harsh winter in the United States. 
The market remains relatively stable and we were pleased that we're able to secure rate increases while again achieving strong renewal retention in all 3 of our business units. Operating income per share was $1.57, a 5% increase over the $1.50 over last year's first quarter. The effective catastrophes were $0.69 per share in this year's first quarter compared to $0.52 per share last year. Annualized operating ROE was 10.2% for the first quarter of this year. The combined ratio for the first quarter was 93.9% this year compared to 93.2% last year. Excluding the impact of cats, the combined ratio for the first quarter improved to 85.8% in 2015 from 86.6% a year ago. Net written premiums which grew 1% were negatively affected by currency. Excluding the effect of foreign currency translation, premiums were up 4%. First quarter net income per share was $1.60 resulting in an annualized ROE of 9.2%.
Cat book value per share at March 31 were $70.33, up slightly from year-end 2014, and a 6% increase since March 31 a year ago. Our capital position is excellent. We continue to actively repurchase our shares. In addition, during the first one, we increased our common stock dividend by 14% to $2.28 per share on an annualized basis. It's Chubb's 33rd consecutive annual dividend increase is a consistent financial performance and financial strength. And now I'll turn it over to Dino.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. In a marketplace that while competitive remains relatively stable with regard to pricing terms and condition, CCI and CPI both have strong performance in the first quarter. Each unit produced solid underwriting profitability and continue to
componenttext:
Thanks, John. In a marketplace that while competitive remains relatively stable with regard to pricing terms and condition, CCI and CPI both have strong performance in the first quarter. Each unit produced solid underwriting profitability and continue to execute our business plan, which emphasizes the retention of our profitable portfolio, while seeking rate increases on those accounts that still require them. We also leverage our distinct underwriting and claims service to write new business in our targeted niche markets. 
Beginning with CCI, the first quarter combined ratio was 90.8 compared to 88.5 in the first quarter of 2014. The first quarter impact of catastrophe losses accounted for 3.4 points of the combined ratio in 2015 and 6.1 points in 2014. Excluding the impact of catastrophes, CCI's combined ratio in the first quarter of 2015 was 87.4 compared to 82.4 in the first quarter of 2014. A 5-point increase was almost all due to a reduction in the amount of favorable prior-year reserve development in CCI, which in turn was mainly driven by a swing from favorable development in the year-ago quarter to modestly adverse development in this year's first quarter in the Commercial Property lines, including Multiple Peril Property. CCI's x cat accident year combined ratio remains very strong at virtually the same level as in the first quarter a year ago.
Drilling down into the CCI lines, the all up Multiple Peril combined ratio was 96.9 compared to 91.8 in the first quarter of 2014 with a similar impact of catastrophes in both periods. Property Marine produced a combined ratio of 89 in the first quarter of this year and 89.1 in the same period last year with a lower impact of cats this year. The cash flow for the combined ratio for the first quarter of 2015 was 93.7, which was higher than the 89.7 we reported for the first quarter last year, but was more in line with our full year results for Casualty last year. And our Workers' Compensation combined ratio continue to be outstanding at 84.1, essentially unchanged from 84 that we posted reported in the first quarter of 2014. 
In recent conference call, we reported to you that the rate of rate increases we have secured for the past several years, we were increasingly focused on retention, while at the same time, taking advantage of better price new business in the market segments we target. This focus is contributing to a positive growth. In CCI, first quarter net written premiums grew 2% to $1.4 billion. Growth excluding the impact of foreign currency translation was about 5%.
The Multiple Peril and Property Marine lines grew at 3% and 1%, respectively, despite the drag from currency. In Workers' Comp, which is largely a U.S. business, growth was a strong 11%. But as we have pointed out in the past, this line can fluctuate substantially from quarter-to-quarter due to the presence or absence of a few larger premium accounts. Lastly, in Casualty net written premiums declined 5%, largely due to the adverse impact of foreign currency translation to a slightly higher than the impact on our overall CCI business due to casualties' higher percentage of business outside the United States in the first quarter.
Overall, renewal retention for CCI in the first quarter was 87% in the U.S. This is in line with our last 3 quarters and high by historical standards. Even with this high retention, we were able to achieve on average written renewal rate increase of 1% for the U.S. book. This was the 16th consecutive quarter in which CCI secured rate increases amounting to 3 years of rate-on-rate. Outside the U.S., CCI's average renewal rate increases in the first quarter were flat to slightly positive.
With respect to the business, we continue to take advantage of our unique expertise in products and services to target the market segments in which we specialize. In the first quarter, in the U.S., our new business ratio was 1.4 to 1 equal to the ratio in the fourth quarter of 2014. This reflects the high retention rate and solid new business writings that we believe will meet our performance targets. Indeed, the vast majority of our new business was written for customers within our proven niche markets. Because we focus almost entirely on this target market segments, where we offer value added products and services as well as unique expertise, winning the business is not exclusively a price-driven transaction but in turn, it also generates strong profit margins over time.
Turning now to Chubb Specialty Insurance, we experience another very strong quarter with a combined ratio of 81.9. This is a 7-point improvement over the first quarter of last year. Professional Liability, which represents the majority of the CFI portfolio, our combined ratio of 85.2 in the first quarter was similar to the 84.6 combined ratio in the first quarter of last year. The continued strong underwriting profitability of our Professional Liability business is a product that our disciplined underwriting, skillful management of the portfolio business mix and calling actions informed use of advanced analytics and predictive modeling. Of course, the compound effect of the rate increases on our U.S. book, which have exceeded 25% since January 2012, also contributed to our excellent combined ratio. 
With respect to growth, Chubb Specialty Insurance net written premiums in the first quarter were flat at $621 million. Growth, excluding the impact of foreign currency translation of about 4%. Net written premiums of the Professional Liability portion of CSI were e down 1% to $545 million, reflecting growth in the United States and the adverse impact of foreign currency translation on our business outside the U.S.
In the first quarter, we secured average renewal rate increases of 4% for Professional Liability in the U.S., just as we did in the fourth quarter of last year. The first quarter was the 14th consecutive quarter that we achieved Professional Liability rate increases in the U.S. Despite our pressing for rate increases, we achieved strong renewal retention of 87% for that book. 
In markets outside the U.S., average renewal rates continued to be flat. In terms of new business, Professional Liability had another good quarter in the U.S. with a new to loss ratio 1.2: 1. As was the case with CCI, our strong underwriting expertise in value-added services enabled us to find better quality opportunities in our target markets following several great years of rate increases and underwriting actions.
Turning now to the Surety portion of the Specialty book. The combined ratio of 54.8 in the first quarter represented a significant improvement over the 2014 first quarter's combined ratio of 122.9, which was adversely impacted by a single large loss. Net written premiums of $76 million were up 6%.
Bottom line for our CSA business overall, we are very pleased with the strategies we have implemented and we are well positioned to continue to grow profitably over time. With that, I'll turn it over to Paul to review our personal insurance operation and corporate-wide claim results.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dino. Chubb personal insurance net written premiums increased 2% to $1 billion in the first quarter of 2015. Growth, excluding the impact of foreign currency translation, was about 5%. CPI produced a combined ratio of 105.1 in the first quarter 20
componenttext:
Thanks, Dino. Chubb personal insurance net written premiums increased 2% to $1 billion in the first quarter of 2015. Growth, excluding the impact of foreign currency translation, was about 5%. CPI produced a combined ratio of 105.1 in the first quarter 2015 compared to 101.8 in the corresponding quarter last year. The impact of catastrophes on CPI's first quarter combined ratio was 18.4 points compared to 11.2 points in the first quarter of 2014. On an x cat basis, CPI's combined ratio was 86.7 in the first quarter of 2015, nearly a 4-point improvement compared to 90.6% in the first quarter a year ago.
For our homeowners line, premiums grew 1% and the combined ratio was 112.7 compared to 104.9 in the corresponding quarter last year. Cat losses accounted for 30 points of the homeowners' combined ratio in the first quarter of 2015 compared to 17.9 points in the first quarter of last year. There were 9 U.S. winter storm catastrophe events in the first quarter which affected 29 states in the District of Columbia. The majority of our losses were from burst pipes and ice damming, most of which occurred in February. While the damage was widespread across much of the Eastern section of the United States, our New York and New England customers were the most affected. 
Excluding the impact of catastrophes, the 2015 first quarter homeowners combined ratio was 82.7, a 4.3-point improvement compared to 87 in the same period a year ago. Most of the improvement is attributable to the fact that fire losses this year were in line with our 5- and 10-year averages, whereas in the first quarter a year ago, fire losses were considerably higher than average. Not surprisingly, the impact of non-cat weather-related losses in the first quarter of 2015 was elevated compared to a typical first quarter. However, it was slightly lower than the first quarter a year ago.
During the first quarter of 2015, we achieved an average homeowners renewal rate and exposure increase of 5% in the United States compared to 6% in the fourth quarter of last year. For our Personal Auto line, net written premiums grew 2% in the first quarter of 2015. The combined ratio was 92.9 compared to an unusually high 101.4 in the corresponding quarter of 2014. U.S. renewal policy retention in the first quarter of 2015 was a very strong 89% for both homeowners and Personal Auto, identical to the fourth quarter of 2014.
Net written premiums for other personal, which includes our accident, personal excess liability and yacht lines, grew 5% in the first quarter. The combined ratio for other personal was 92.3 in the first quarter, consistent with a combined ratio of 92.4 in the first quarter a year ago.
Turning now to first quarter claims corporate-wide. As we announced on April 7, we had catastrophe losses of $250 million before tax or 8.1 points on the combined ratio compared to $199 million or 6.6 points in the first quarter of 2014. The $250 million in this year's first quarter reflected about $264 million from 2015 cat events, almost entirely from the ones in the United States. Slightly offset by a $14 million decrease in our estimated losses from catastrophes which occurred in prior years. In the first quarter this year, roughly 80% of the total catastrophe losses were attributable to CPI and 20% to CCI. 
And with that, I will turn it over to Ricky, who will review our financial results in more detail.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Paul. As usual, I will discuss our financial results for the quarter and I will also provide an update on the April 1 renewal of our major property reinsurance program. Looking first at our operating results, underwriting income was $205 mill
componenttext:
Thank you, Paul. As usual, I will discuss our financial results for the quarter and I will also provide an update on the April 1 renewal of our major property reinsurance program. 
Looking first at our operating results, underwriting income was $205 million in the quarter. Property and Casualty investment income after tax was down 5% to $264 million, due once again to lower reinvestment rate in our fixed maturity portfolios and to a lesser extent, the impact of foreign currency translation. Net income was slightly higher than operating income in the quarter due to net realized investment gains before tax of $11 million or $0.03 per share after-tax, including $0.03 per share from alternative investments. For comparison, in the first quarter of 2014, we had net realized investment gains before tax of $116 million or $0.30 per share after-tax, including $0.14 per share from alternative investments. Unrealized depreciation before tax at March 31 was $2.9 billion compared to $2.7 billion at year-end 2014. The total carrying value of our consolidated investment portfolio was $43 billion as of March 31, 2015. The composition of our portfolio remains largely unchanged from the prior quarter. The average duration of our fixed maturity portfolio is 4.1 years and the average credit rating is AA grade. 
We continue to have excellent liquidity at the holding company. At March 31, our holding company portfolio had $1.8 billion of investment, including approximately $470 million of short-term investments. Book value per share under GAAP at March 31 was $70.33 compared to $70.12 at year-end 2014. Adjusted book value per share, which we calculate with available for sale fixed maturities at amortized costs were $64.75 compared to $65.03 at 2014 year-end. the change in book value per share and the change in adjusted book value per share for the first quarter 2015 both reflected an adverse impact of approximately $0.77 due to foreign currency translation.
As for loss reserves, we estimate that we had favorable development in the first quarter of 2015 on prior year reserves by SBU as follows: In CCI, we had approximately $5 million; CCI, had $35 million; CSI had $70 million; and reinsurance assumed had none, bringing our total favorable development to approximately $110 million for the quarter. This represents a favorable impact on the first quarter combined ratio of about 3.5 points overall including a favorable impact of prior year catastrophes of $14 million. For comparison, in the first quarter 2014, we had about $160 million of favorable development for the company overall, including $5 million in CPI, $90 million in CCI, $65 million in CSI and none in reinsurance assumed. The favorable impact on the combined ratio in the first quarter of 2014 was about 5.5 points, including a favorable impact of prior year catastrophes of $7 million. For the first quarter 2015, our x cat accident year combined ratio was 88.9 compared to 91.7 in last year's first quarter an improvement of 2.8 points. During the first quarter, our loss reserves decreased by $107 million. The impact of foreign currency translation on loss reserves during the quarter resulted in a decrease in reserves of about $370 million and the effect of cats was increased reserves by $184 million.
Turning to capital management. We repurchased 3.2 million shares at an aggregate cost of $326 million during the quarter. The average cost of our repurchases in the quarter was $100.77 per share. At the end of the first quarter, we had $1 billion available for share repurchases under our current authorization. And as we've said on our last earnings call, we expect to complete this program by the end of January 2016. In addition, as John mentioned, our board raised the quarterly common stock dividend in February by 14% to $0.50 -- $0.57 per share or $2.28 on an annual basis. 
I would now like to say a few words about our reinsurance program. On April 1, we renewed our major Property treaties, including our North American cat treaty, our non-U.S. cat treaty and our Commercial Property for risk treaty. We renewed these programs with a similar limit structure to what we had in 2014, but with expanded coverage and improved terms and condition. The reinsurance market was orderly and there was plenty of capacity meet our needs in each treaty. As you might expect, we're in a attractively seated [ph] We achieved meaningful savings on all 3 treaties again this year, with double-digit price decreases on our 2 major catastrophe treaties, as well as a high single-digit price decrease on the Commercial Property for risk treaty. 
In addition, in March, we successfully completed our seventh catastrophe bond offering to replace the maturing cat line. The transaction was very well received by the market and this enabled us to replace the existing limit of $250 million and expand the perils covered relative to the expiring arrangement at attractive pricing. Under this new arrangement, we purchased fully collateralized 5-year coverage to supplement our reinsurance program for our Commercial and Personal Property exposures in the Northeast United States, running from Virginia to Maine. In terms of pricing, the coupon of the new cap bond is approximately 45% lower than the maturing bond. 
Similar to our previous cat bonds, we had that indemnity based trigger, which means that our right to correct is based on actual incurred losses as opposed to industry or index-based losses. We like the diversification of these cat bond arrangements with our overall reinsurance program, especially in our peak zones. Importantly, they provide us with a cost-effective, fully-collateralized alternative to traditional reinsurance with price locked in for several years. 
And now I'll turn it back to John.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ricky. As you can see, the start of the quarter was a harsh winter weather in the United States which drove catastrophe losses of $250 million. These cat losses reduced our operating income by $0.69 per share after-tax. Nonetheless we're still abl
componenttext:
Thanks, Ricky. As you can see, the start of the quarter was a harsh winter weather in the United States which drove catastrophe losses of $250 million. These cat losses reduced our operating income by $0.69 per share after-tax. Nonetheless we're still able to achieve operating income of $1.57 in the quarter reflecting strong cat performance. Our x cat accident year combined ratio was an excellent 88.9% which is 2.8 points of improvement over the first quarter of last year. 
We are pleased with our x currency growth of 4% in the quarter. In the U.S., retention rates remained at high levels and we're able to achieve renewal rate increases generally in line with the prior quarter. We also continue to focus on capital management in the quarter, raising our dividend by 14% and repurchasing 3.2 million shares at an aggregate cost of $326 million. 
And with that, I'll open the line to questions.

componenttext: So I'd love to just to start big picture around pricing. Over the past companies, John, I think you talked a lot about how generally concerned underwriters look to kind of cover the cost of something like 3% to 4% assumption for long-term loss trends and it doesn't really work that you need all that. But with pricing now more like 1% to 2% in a lot of places, should we be thinking simplistically that, that means that the businesses margins or were going to start to decline? Or what's really it's the current business really adequately priced and in the 1% to 2%, you're going to be able to run them around in place and maintain the margins over the next few years.

componenttext: Josh, first, let's level a second. 1% to 2% of CCI, I mean that's a big part of our business but it's not the majority of the business. Professional Liability was 4% in the U.S. Personal lines was 5% in the U.S. So you when you look at it and if you look now for 2015 accident year, you're obviously also getting a benefit of the lag impact of rent premium based on written premium that was higher in 2014, right? So if you look at the 2015 accident year, and then you look at loss trends, which you properly stated, 3% to 4% -- 4%, 3% of long term, we've made a point of saying that still the macroeconomic will take you tack on the underwriting action, we believe 2 to 3 points, let's say 3 points is a reasonable action. So if you look at that, I'd say all of our businesses, in the U.S., will really probably on unearned premium basis in 2015 accident year, a little bit margin neutral to slightly margin profit positive. We CCI, the what you alluded to be a margin negative to some degree, but even CCI at current rates will have 2 point premiums so it will only slightly negative. Professional Liability, being slightly positive in the U.S. and personal lines, being 1 point or 2 point positive and it's a couple of points positive. So obviously, the challenge is in CCI, but right now, it's not a terrible place to be. But overall, from an overall book, 2015 accident year, it's not necessarily implied margin contraction, could be margin neutral to slightly positive at today's rates in the U.S., now you obviously had to have the assumption the rates are going and that could change it. Although again, you basically 5 quarters and after 2013 accident year rate.

componenttext: That's helpful. I'm wondering if we could just shift gears a little bit. But there's a lot of energy and interest and focus set of targeting the sector and then kind of curious how you're thinking about either, I guess I'm strategies or maybe tactics to actually minting your position and really continue to grow that business over time.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Josh, this is Paul. I'll take a stab at your question. First off, yes, we're all anxious to make enough to get that yacht, and hopefully get there soon. But I would start off by just level setting. There is a lot of energy around the high net worth space,
componenttext: Josh, this is Paul. I'll take a stab at your question. First off, yes, we're all anxious to make enough to get that yacht, and hopefully get there soon. But I would start off by just level setting. There is a lot of energy around the high net worth space, amongst the small handful of competitors here, especially in the United States. And I think what exciting people about is there is a real opportunity to differentiate and to also take market share from regional carriers and from the direct writers. I would estimate that about 80% of the high net worth space is this large direct writer's and regional carriers, often times just by default. Somebody comes out of business school and ends up being with a buddy from high school who's a local agent, and they tend to stay there for 10 or 15, 20 years and they really don't know what an independent ratio can bring to the party and what Chubb personal lines can bring to the party. So one of the tricks in the energy around us is to have certain campaigns there trying to fuel people out of the direct writer market. Another is to make certain that we're working very closely with our agents to educate them, so they speak the language of the high net worth and the ultrahigh net worth people. We're obviously adding to our products as well so that we can service them. Clearly, our international network gives us a huge advantage when it comes to the ultra high net worth. Because as we all know, they have their homes and they park there yet in exotic place and that type of thing. Clearly, the fine art market is another thing. The art schedules are absolutely staggering for a lot of these families and we have the ability to put together hundreds of millions of dollars in art coverage on a single phone call. So we have deep expertise when it comes to appraisal, to preservation. just for example, we have I think 17 fine art specialists around the globe that are working on just helping with our customers preserve those fine art and that type of thing. So a lot of it is around products, a lot of it is around service, but we're working very hard to make certain that our independent agents have the ability to really sell to these families and the know-how to go out and try them out of channels that they're currently not tapping into.

There's 2 different products and we're Chubb is in both of those product other that. But when I think about that, that sounds like mass affluent to me, not yacht and paintings. What's the market opportunity for growth in 2 different markets, locally in the United States and internationally.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Josh. First off, I think we break it down -- well, we break it down a lot in 3 broad strikes. The first is the signature which is the ultrahigh net worth. Then we have our VIP clients, and then we have what you're kind of referring to as mass affl
componenttext: Thanks, Josh. First off, I think we break it down -- well, we break it down a lot in 3 broad strikes. The first is the signature which is the ultrahigh net worth. Then we have our VIP clients, and then we have what you're kind of referring to as mass affluent. We just call them our regular masterpiece customers. And I do think is where are a lot of the market decides that we can take away from the other channels. I'd tell you, that's one of the areas where we believe we have a real distinct advantage against our high net worth carriers who are obviously trying to build some scale there. But we've had our masterpiece, product vehicle and our back office set up for over 30 years right now. So quite frankly, when an agent comes to us with a block or a book of mass affluent customers, frankly, what's so attractive is we have the back office to help them and can handle that volume. So we really have offerings for those 3 broad swathes of the market.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: As I said in the last piece, Josh, if you think about 80% of high net worth space is with carriers who don't specialize in the high net worth space. I'm not going to say that they're with the wrong carrier because I think everybody who'd not with us is wi
componenttext: As I said in the last piece, Josh, if you think about 80% of high net worth space is with carriers who don't specialize in the high net worth space. I'm not going to say that they're with the wrong carrier because I think everybody who'd not with us is with the wrong carrier, but it just seems as you all know. When it comes to the ultrahigh net worth and are they underinsured, I would tell you'd be surprised how many of them don't, for example, carry more than say $5 million in excess liability coverage and I'm always shocked when we sit down with them and talk to them about our ability to handle tens of millions of dollars in excess liability. And then when we sit with them and we get them to get their artwork, for example, independently appraised, that market is absolutely on fire. And depending on their collection, it's not -- I don't see a week that goes by were somebody isn't bumping up there our schedule at least by $10 million to $15 million in value and that's just off their current collection.

componenttext: And then I would get off one last question. Would all that going on, I guess I would imagine that you have more growth than we're seeing right now against that backdrop. headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: When it comes to competition, I always have a hard time distinguishing between competitive, highly competitive. I've been doing this for so long and I was always competitive, just as a basis of that. I think the trick for Chubb and others that are in this
componenttext: When it comes to competition, I always have a hard time distinguishing between competitive, highly competitive. I've been doing this for so long and I was always competitive, just as a basis of that. I think the trick for Chubb and others that are in this space will be around going after those people that are not in the channel. Clearly, it's not just creating accounts with a couple of other carriers and taking margin out of them. So that's where I think the struggle is in the United States. Clearly, we're growing other places. I'd say if you're looking at our overall growth, it was down a little bit, but you had to remember that were also overseas and currency impacted us on the home owners business, in particular the Canadian dollar, the British pound and the euro, so and then as well, the Brazilian real came down. So those currencies all impacted our growth.

componenttext: Got it, got it. And I guess, one question I have, just bigger picture, I guess, on volatility of earnings and these losses recently. componenttext: We've obviously prefer less volatility, if I get it. I think we're going to be subject to a little bit more given our concentration in the Northeast, and its being prone to weather disruptions. But having said that, I had a talked -- we've been surprisingly volatile last 2 years, 5 quarters, 2 or 3 quarters, but the fact was 2013, we ran a 3.6 cat load, and 2014 after initial 6 point first quarter and 10 point first half, 5 points on average a year, we ran a 3.62. So we really didn't have unduly high caps over the last couple of years. If you go back to a couple years before that, obviously which was back-to-back storms like that unprecedented, worst problems. But we've got a quarterly blip here or there, but cats have not until we process some in 2013 and 2014.

componenttext: Yes, it's Ricky. I would say broadly no. We like the diversification that we get from having our international businesses. Paul mentioned we think it's a competitive advantage in a number of our business lines as well. We're very thoughtful about how we manage currency risk. We match assets and liabilities in the local currencies to try to minimize any potential currency exposures so. I would say from a strategic standpoint, no changes anticipated. We're very happy with our international operations and their overall performance.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015

componenttext: No, not currency unless you thought it was permanent. But it's obviously more -- it is a more complicated issue. I mean, it might decrease your appetite if you thought the economies of the countries before and of course, we have some -- Europe has had some issues. You have no issues with Brazil in terms of their economy. Currency is part and parcel of it, but as economies remain strong, we can write business in the right profitable business, it won't change our strategy.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just an unrelated question, I think you have a successful piece of your business where you have outsourced the claims. Maybe you could talk about sort of where you think outside the obvious maybe and the personalized business, but your Commercial business
componenttext: Just an unrelated question, I think you have a successful piece of your business where you have outsourced the claims. Maybe you could talk about sort of where you think outside the obvious maybe and the personalized business, but your Commercial business, where you think you really should have control on those claims versus places where it's not as important.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, this is Paul. I would tell you that the area where the -- where we typically use third-party administrators is in the Accident & Health business, and the reality is there. It's often times, say business policies will have things like a lost luggage
componenttext: Sure, this is Paul. I would tell you that the area where the -- where we typically use third-party administrators is in the Accident & Health business, and the reality is there. It's often times, say business policies will have things like a lost luggage writer on them, and this is very -- it's just not economically feasible to have a Chubb adjuster sitting in the United States handling a $5,000 piece of lost luggage. So and quite frankly, these programs are often sold through affinity groups, say a bank credit card outside the United States. So and they're not really looking for the Chubb handholding apathetic claims experience. The only other places where we really used outside third-party administrators to any degree would be around large risk management accounts in the Commercial space where they actually request that and they're breaking their the cost structure that way. I don't know, Dino, if you want to add anything to that?

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, no, I think that's a good description.
componenttext: No, no, I think that's a good description.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: And a loss of a secondary home up in Alaska or something and it's just easier for us to use a third-party administrator to go up and look at that type of a claim and supply somebody up from Seattle. So that's -- we have great relationships with those peop
componenttext: And a loss of a secondary home up in Alaska or something and it's just easier for us to use a third-party administrator to go up and look at that type of a claim and supply somebody up from Seattle. So that's -- we have great relationships with those people, and obviously have contracts with them as well, and we have what we call Chubb business consultants that oversee those individual relationships and make certain that if we use an outside vendor that they live up to our standard.

componenttext: One of the other major P&C companies this quarter said that they thought that the amplitude of the commercial insurance cycle could be less severe going forward. And as pricing heads towards negative territory in Commercial lines, I'm just wondering if you would agree with that or if you have a different view.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean, it's Dino. I mean, it's difficult to know what's going to happen. I mean clearly, there are some things in the industry that would have you suggest that there's potentially some structural changes to the cycle, obviously the low investment returns
componenttext: I mean, it's Dino. I mean, it's difficult to know what's going to happen. I mean clearly, there are some things in the industry that would have you suggest that there's potentially some structural changes to the cycle, obviously the low investment returns that you make, some of the increased analytics that are being used, some of the regulatory scrutiny, et cetera. Really in these last several years, if you call it a hard market, you really didn't see rate increases the way you saw them in the last hard market cycle. So hopefully, that pertains that you're not going to see larger rate decreases. But we'll see, we'll have to see how the cycle plays out.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then my follow-up question is on reserve releases. If my data is correct, it looks like reserve releases of $110 million in the quarter, even including the benefit of favorable part of your cat development is the lowest level of any quarter in 3
componenttext: Okay. And then my follow-up question is on reserve releases. If my data is correct, it looks like reserve releases of $110 million in the quarter, even including the benefit of favorable part of your cat development is the lowest level of any quarter in 3 years. So I think a concern would be that this reserve release tailwind, all of a sudden becomes headwind. How are you preparing for that? And do you think that's a possible outcome?

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Coming at it from both sides, I mean I think that in past calls, especially when asked about our guidance and what's favorable development was implied with that, we had no specific levels of favorable development implied, but that over the long run, it se
componenttext: Coming at it from both sides, I mean I think that in past calls, especially when asked about our guidance and what's favorable development was implied with that, we had no specific levels of favorable development implied, but that over the long run, it seems hard to believe that we can definitely sustain 6 points of favorable development. That proved generally you wrong, although we've had some incremental development say 1.5 points from 2010 to 2014 but that's 6.5 to 5 is pretty darn good. So pretty robust, and I think it's benefiting us in a surprising aspect of the overall reserve development because that's actually been up significantly and it's been sustained at such strong level. And you're right, the first quarter was 3.5 points. And if we can move around quite a bit significant individual quarter but it's a significant trend. So give you an example -- 2 examples. The government was curious about the about the fourth quarter of 2013 and the first quarter of 2010 were $100 million to $115 million, very similar to what we have experienced in the first quarter. The same concern could have been raised for both periods. As it turns out development rebounded sharply in the the ensuing quarters. So in retrospect these less favorable development quarters turned out to be blips rather than the tipping point in the level of development. So I can't say whether or not this also true with the development in the balance of 2015. In the end, our reserves over time is function of actually loss experienced which is obviously different to predict. But I do think that could be pretty immature to drive conclusion based on first quarter results.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015

componenttext: No, this year -- we got hurt in the short-tail lines come and it's a live it a seasonal factor than short-term lines and they don't last long, right? So the Property, homeowners lines, you see more development one way or another in the first quarter and the fourth quarter of the year. And this year it wasn't -- we have a couple ascendant was in that negative effect. And last year, it was more positive, so that's the kind of focus I can turn around.

To make a difference as to whether we have favorable development or adverse development in the quarter. componenttext: And that's on the CCI side. In the other areas, so in CPI, most of the favorable development came from our Personal Auto book. Again, the Property lines were not as favorable this time around. And then in CSI, it was driven mainly as it's been for the last number of quarters, driven mainly by Professional Liability, but we also were favorable in Surety as well.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015

componenttext: Okay, that's great. Then on your guidance, and it looks like the first quarter cats accounted probably, by my calculation roughly like 50% of your full-year budget in your original guidance. So I just wonder, you didn't change your guidance this time you said because that gives you confidence in the remainder of the year you'll catch up or just timing issue, your typical update your guidance at the second quarter earnings.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I'm not sure I can ever say I'm confident what cat is going to look like. I would say that one quarter certainly, as you heard John say, doesn't the year make, and I'll use the example, use it as well. But last year in the first quarter, we have ove
componenttext: Well, I'm not sure I can ever say I'm confident what cat is going to look like. I would say that one quarter certainly, as you heard John say, doesn't the year make, and I'll use the example, use it as well. But last year in the first quarter, we have over 6.5 points of catastrophe losses and we ended up the year at only 3.6 points of losses which were below our expectations coming into the year. So we're not revisiting guidance at this time, we're not reaffirming guidance at this time. As you point out, we normally do we look at guidance at midyear, and we'll potentially address this then. But at this point, it's way too premature.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Lastly, if I may, your reinsurance program looks like the prices have come down quite a bit. So what you saw about buying more reinsurance that lower limits and could potentially lower your earnings volatility.
componenttext: Okay. Lastly, if I may, your reinsurance program looks like the prices have come down quite a bit. So what you saw about buying more reinsurance that lower limits and could potentially lower your earnings volatility.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, what I'd say, and I think I said this on a couple of recent calls, we're always looking at ways to potentially use reinsurance if we think it makes sense to either lower volatility or help our growth or help our bottom line results. We're quite comf
componenttext: Well, what I'd say, and I think I said this on a couple of recent calls, we're always looking at ways to potentially use reinsurance if we think it makes sense to either lower volatility or help our growth or help our bottom line results. We're quite comfortable with the reinsurance program we have today. We're constantly looking at new ideas. We put a couple things in place in some of our businesses. But we've never been heavy users of reinsurance. And we're not going to change our overall strategy the way that we approach the business. We're generally gross underwriters, and we use the reinsurance, if we think it helps us, but it's never that simple to just say it's cheaper today and therefore makes sense. We don't like giving away profitability if we don't need to.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'd say from the first quarter, there'll be no reinsurance program that would mitigate our cost. I mean, the biggest storm was $150 million. I mean, no one I mean, in the industry is carrying first coverage on reinsurance. I mean, that would be extremely
componenttext: I'd say from the first quarter, there'll be no reinsurance program that would mitigate our cost. I mean, the biggest storm was $150 million. I mean, no one I mean, in the industry is carrying first coverage on reinsurance. I mean, that would be extremely expensive. So this isn't the type of storm that's usually subject to having a reinsurance coverage on the storms towards, right that.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Paul. As I mentioned before, this lines contains our A&H portfolio and the expense ratio move up and down based on how much more A&H business we write in each period. And since A&H has higher expense ratio, but obviously has a lower loss rati
componenttext: Yes, this is Paul. As I mentioned before, this lines contains our A&H portfolio and the expense ratio move up and down based on how much more A&H business we write in each period. And since A&H has higher expense ratio, but obviously has a lower loss ratio profile than the other CPI businesses. But then even within the accident business, there can be real frustrations driven primarily by the volume of affinity accident business that I talked about before, where we're sourcing through, say, a department store or a credit card issuer, that type of a thing, because that's where we have the highest expense ratio in all of our accident business. So really depending upon the affinity volume within the overall mix of the accident and then accident within the other personal, but that's where we see the expense ratio up and down a little bit. Bottom line, it came down a little bit because of the movement within accident, but I won't suggest that that's of bellwether or a new low that we're going to be running with in the future.

componenttextpreview: Yes, as I mentioned, the we're getting probably flat to slightly positive rate activity, and our retention ratios outside the U.S. are essentially close to what they are in the U.S., sort of mid 80s, 85, 86, 87 rate. It's interesting, the rate has been qu
componenttext: Yes, as I mentioned, the we're getting probably flat to slightly positive rate activity, and our retention ratios outside the U.S. are essentially close to what they are in the U.S., sort of mid 80s, 85, 86, 87 rate. It's interesting, the rate has been quite stable, actually. They've been traditionally lower than the increases we were getting in the U.S., but it's essentially stayed there, so it's in the flat to slightly positive.

componenttext: Great. So I guess my first question was I guess also some of the and in particular, I guess in Commercial. componenttextpreview: I think reasonably across the floor. But I wouldn't point at the beginning of a trend. It was a good quarter, but quarters fluctuate. And given the fact we are not getting a sizable amount of rate overseas, it'd be hard to say whether it's going to be hug
componenttext: I think reasonably across the floor. But I wouldn't point at the beginning of a trend. It was a good quarter, but quarters fluctuate. And given the fact we are not getting a sizable amount of rate overseas, it'd be hard to say whether it's going to be huge improvements on the term line basis. Obviously, the quarter fluctuate smooth gloss fluctuations. A lot of that is lost with a good bit of underwriting in place. But I wouldn't read too much into it. I think the last few quarters were a little high and this was pretty good, we'll see.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: And one more, I guess, just on the capital return philosophy. I guess last quarter, you guys give us a share repurchase authorization was a little less than last year and I guess he also indicated you felt good about our capital position. And you said tha
componenttext: And one more, I guess, just on the capital return philosophy. I guess last quarter, you guys give us a share repurchase authorization was a little less than last year and I guess he also indicated you felt good about our capital position. And you said that the reason it was a little less than last year was you like to be able to move it around maybe based on what the share price is. Just curious if Chubb would consider deployment of capital in some other form other than share repo. And I guess, longer term along those lines, how does Chubb think about the right amount of capital that's required to kind of support the risk of this business in the cycle? And how does that compare to the way the businesses is currently capitalized.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, it's Ricky, I'll take a shot at answering that. First off, I think what we've said last quarter when we announced the new share repurchase was that it's sort of in line with what we expected earnings are for the year less shareholder dividend. And t
componenttext: Sure, it's Ricky, I'll take a shot at answering that. First off, I think what we've said last quarter when we announced the new share repurchase was that it's sort of in line with what we expected earnings are for the year less shareholder dividend. And that's sort of the overall philosophy. It wasn't the stock price that drove the size of our share repurchase. We have a philosophy that we've articulated over the last few years that our intent, obviously, market conditions and other things all being equal, that our share buyback in essence be in line with our earnings less shareholder dividend, and that's how we came up with the size of the program. We do believe that we have a very strong excess capital position. We do -- we think very -- we think a lot about our deployment of capital and what's the right amount, and we think about all the different types of capital deployment strategies. We're very comfortable with our share repurchase. In years past, if you've looked at what we've done, we've had more opportunity from a valuation or others, we might do something slightly larger us than our earnings less dividends. So we're very careful about how we manage it and we're very aware of being good stewards of our capital for our shareholders. So we do think about all the different options. I'm not going to comment on which ones we may or may not think about in the future. I also point out, as John mentioned, we've increased our common dividend for the last 33 years, which is another piece of how we manage our capital position. So again, in sum, we feel very good about where we are and the way we approach this, and nothing really different than what we've been doing over a number of years.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our final question will come from Jay Cohen from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our final question will come from Jay Cohen from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Most of my questions have been answered. Just one quick one. The currency impact, as you think short term the next several quarters, would you expect the impact on premiums from the stronger dollar to be similar to the first quarter, stronger or weaker?
componenttext: Most of my questions have been answered. Just one quick one. The currency impact, as you think short term the next several quarters, would you expect the impact on premiums from the stronger dollar to be similar to the first quarter, stronger or weaker?

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think it's obviously -- it depends on the comparison of the movement of currency quarter-to-quarter. I would think that in the second and third quarters -- remember, most of the currency movement that has happened started in the fourth quarter of last y
componenttext: I think it's obviously -- it depends on the comparison of the movement of currency quarter-to-quarter. I would think that in the second and third quarters -- remember, most of the currency movement that has happened started in the fourth quarter of last year and continued then into the first quarter of this year. So all other things being equal, currency stays where it was at the end of March then you will still see an impact on growth in certainly the second and third quarters. And I'm not saying whether it will be similar to what we have in the first quarter, I don't know, but certainly there will be an impact. And the guidance that we put in January, we did say that we expect a full impact for the full year, so maybe that can give you some help there as well. As John mentioned, from an earnings perspective, it doesn't have a very large impact on the quarterly basis, a couple of cents a share in the first quarter. Bear in mind, when you think about the investment income piece, a large part of our after-tax investment income comes from the municipal bond portfolio here in the U.S., so it's a slightly disproportionate impact on investment income in the U.S. Last point I'd make on book value is again, if currencies don't change from where they were at the end of March, which is a pretty big assumption, the impact on book value will probably be meaningfully less in the second quarter than it was in the first quarter. It won't be 0 because we have some of our foreign operations that report on a one quarter lag, which we highlighted in our 10-K, so there will be an impact but it shouldn't be nearly as large as it was in the first quarter. Hopefully, that gives you some help.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015

componenttext: Great. Operator? I think we're finished.
