componenttext: Thank you.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to The Chubb Corporation's First Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded.Before we begin, Chubb has asked me to make the following statements: In order to help you understand Chubb, its indus
componenttext:
Good day, everyone, and welcome to The Chubb Corporation's First Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded.
Before we begin, Chubb has asked me to make the following statements: In order to help you understand Chubb, its industry and its results, members of Chubb's management team will include in today's presentation forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. It is possible that actual results might differ from estimates and forecasts that Chubb's management team makes today. Additional information regarding factors that could cause such differences appears in Chubb's filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
In their prepared remarks and responses to questions during today's presentation, Chubb's management may refer to financial measures that are not derived from generally accepted accounting principles or GAAP. Reconciliations of these non-GAAP financial measures to the most direct comparable GAAP measures and related information are provided in a press release and financial supplement for the first quarter 2015, which are available on the Investors section of Chubb's website at www.chubb.com.
Please also note that no portion of this conference call may be reproduced or rebroadcast in any form without Chubb's prior written consent. Replays of this webcast will be available through Friday, May 22, 2015. Those listening after April 23, 2015, should please note that the information and forecast provided in this recording will not necessarily be updated, and it is possible that the information will no longer be current.
Now I will turn the call over to Mr. Finnegan.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you for joining us. As we said in our press release, Chubb produced solid financial results in the first quarter of 2015. These were achieved even with the adverse impact of both cat and non-cat weather-related losses, primarily in the Homeowners li
componenttext:
Thank you for joining us. As we said in our press release, Chubb produced solid financial results in the first quarter of 2015. These were achieved even with the adverse impact of both cat and non-cat weather-related losses, primarily in the Homeowners line, stemming from the harsh winter in the United States.
The market remained relatively stable, and we were pleased that we're able to secure rate increases while again achieving strong renewal retention in all 3 of our business units. Operating income per share was $1.57, a 5% increase over the $1.50 in last year's first quarter. The effect of catastrophes were $0.69 per share in this year's first quarter compared to $0.52 per share in last year's. Annualized operating ROE was 10.2% for the first quarter of this year. The combined ratio for the first quarter was 93.9% this year compared to 93.2% last year. Excluding the impact of cats, the combined ratio for the first quarter improved to 85.8% in 2015 from 86.6% a year ago. Net written premiums, which grew 1%, were negatively affected by currency. Excluding the effect of foreign currency translation, premiums were up 4%. First quarter net income per share was $1.60 resulting in an annualized ROE of 9.2%.
Cat book value per share at March 31 was $70.33, up slightly from year-end 2014 and a 6% increase since March 31 a year ago. Our capital position is excellent. We continue to actively repurchase our shares. In addition, during the first quarter, we increased our common stock dividend by 14% to $2.28 per share on an annualized basis. It was Chubb's 33rd consecutive annual dividend increase, a continued indication of our consistent performance and financial strength.
And now I'll turn it over to Dino.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. In a marketplace that, while competitive, remained relatively stable with regard to pricing terms and conditions, CCI and CSI both had strong performance in the first quarter. Each unit produced solid underwriting profitability and continued
componenttext:
Thanks, John. In a marketplace that, while competitive, remained relatively stable with regard to pricing terms and conditions, CCI and CSI both had strong performance in the first quarter. Each unit produced solid underwriting profitability and continued to execute our business plan, which emphasizes the retention of our profitable portfolio while seeking rate increases on those accounts that still require them. We also leveraged our distinct underwriting and claims service advantages to write new business in our targeted niche markets.
Beginning with CCI. The first quarter combined ratio was 90.8% compared to 88.5% in the first quarter of 2014. The first quarter impact of catastrophe losses accounted for 3.4 points of the combined ratio in 2015 and 6.1 points in 2014. Excluding the impact of catastrophes, CCI's combined ratio in the first quarter of 2015 was 87.4% compared to 82.4% in the first quarter of 2014. This 5-point increase was almost all due to a reduction in the amount of favorable prior year reserve development in CCI, which, in turn, was mainly driven by a swing from favorable development in the year-ago quarter to modestly adverse development in this year's first quarter in the commercial property lines, including Multiple Peril Property. CCI's x-cat accident year combined ratio remained very strong at virtually the same level as in the first quarter a year ago.
Drilling down into the CCI lines, the all-up Multiple Peril combined ratio was 96.9% compared to 91.8% in the first quarter of 2014 with a similar impact of catastrophes in both periods. Property and Marine produced a combined ratio of 89% in the first quarter of this year and 89.1% in the same period last year with a lower impact of cats this year. The Casualty combined ratio for the first quarter of 2015 was 93.7%, which was higher than the 89.7% we reported for the first quarter last year but was more in line with our full year results for Casualty last year. And our Workers' Compensation combined ratio continued to be outstanding at 84.1%, essentially unchanged from the 84% that we posted in the first quarter of 2014.
In recent conference calls, we reported to you that in light of the rate increases we have secured for the past several years, we were increasingly focused on retention while at the same time, taking advantage of better-priced new business in the market segments we target. This focus is contributing to our positive growth. In CCI, first quarter net written premiums grew 2% to $1.4 billion. Growth, excluding the impact of foreign currency translation, was about 5%.
The Multiple Peril and Property and Marine lines grew at 3% and 1%, respectively, despite the drag from currency. In Workers' Comp, which is largely a U.S. business, growth was a strong 11%, but as we have pointed out in the past, this line can fluctuate substantially from quarter-to-quarter due to the presence or absence of a few larger premium accounts. Lastly, in Casualty, net written premiums declined 5% largely due to the adverse impact of foreign currency translation to a slightly higher than the impact on our overall CCI business due to Casualty's higher percentage of business outside the United States in the first quarter.
Overall, renewal retention for CCI in the first quarter was 87% in the U.S. This is in line with our last 3 quarters and high by historical standards. Even with this high retention, we were able to achieve an average written renewal rate increase of 1% for the U.S. book. This was the 16th consecutive quarter in which CCI secured rate increases amounting to 3 years of rate on rate. Outside the U.S., CCI's average renewal rate increases in the first quarter were flat to slightly positive.
With respect to new business, we continue to take advantage of our unique expertise in products and services to target the market segments in which we specialize. In the first quarter, in the U.S., our new to lost business ratio was 1.4:1, equal to the ratio in the fourth quarter of 2014. This reflects the high retention rate and solid new business writings that we believe will meet our performance targets. Indeed, the vast majority of our new business was written for customers within our proven niche markets. Because we focus almost entirely on those target market segments, where we offer value-added products and services as well as unique expertise, winning the business is not exclusively a price-driven transaction, which in turn, helps us generate strong profit margins over time.
Turning now to Chubb Specialty Insurance, we experienced another very strong quarter with a combined ratio of 81.9%. This is a 7-point improvement over the first quarter of last year. Professional Liability, which represents the majority of the CSI portfolio, our combined ratio of 85.2% in the first quarter was similar to the 84.6% combined ratio in the first quarter of last year. The continued strong underwriting profitability of our Professional Liability business is a product of our disciplined underwriting, skillful management of the portfolio's business mix and calling actions informed by use of advanced analytics and predictive modeling. Of course, the compound effect of the rate increases on our U.S. book, which have exceeded 25% since January 2012, also contributed to our excellent combined ratio.
With respect to growth, Chubb Specialty Insurance net written premiums in the first quarter were flat at $621 million. Growth, excluding the impact of foreign currency translation, was about 4%. Net written premiums of the Professional Liability portion of CSI were down 1% to $545 million, reflecting growth in the United States and the adverse impact of foreign currency translation on our business outside the U.S.
In the first quarter, we secured average renewal rate increases of 4% for Professional Liability in the U.S. just as we did in the fourth quarter of last year. The first quarter was the 14th consecutive quarter that we achieved Professional Liability rate increases in the U.S. Despite our pressing for rate increases, we achieved strong renewal retention of 87% for that book. In markets outside the U.S., average renewal rates continued to be flat.
In terms of new business, Professional Liability had another good quarter in the U.S. with a new to loss ratio 1.2:1. As was the case with CCI, our strong underwriting expertise in value-added services enabled us to find better quality opportunities in our target markets following several great years of rate increases and underwriting actions.
Turning now to the Surety portion of the Specialty book. The combined ratio of 54.8% in the first quarter represented a significant improvement over the 2014 first quarter's combined ratio of 122.9%, which was adversely impacted by a single large loss. Net written premiums of $76 million were up 6%.
Bottom line, for our CSI business overall, we are very pleased with the strategies we have implemented, and we are well positioned to continue to grow profitably over time. With that, I'll turn it over to Paul, who will review our Personal Insurance operation and corporate-wide claim results.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dino. Chubb Personal Insurance net written premiums increased 2% to $1 billion in the first quarter of 2015. Growth, excluding the impact of foreign currency translation, was about 5%. CPI produced a combined ratio of 105.1% in the first quarter o
componenttext:
Thanks, Dino. Chubb Personal Insurance net written premiums increased 2% to $1 billion in the first quarter of 2015. Growth, excluding the impact of foreign currency translation, was about 5%. CPI produced a combined ratio of 105.1% in the first quarter of  2015 compared to 101.8% in the corresponding quarter last year. The impact of catastrophes on CPI's first quarter combined ratio was 18.4 points compared to 11.2 points in the first quarter of 2014. On an x-cat basis, CPI's combined ratio was 86.7% in the first quarter of 2015, nearly a 4-point improvement compared to 90.6% in the first quarter a year ago.
For our Homeowners line, premiums grew 1%, and the combined ratio was 112.7% compared to 104.9% in the corresponding quarter last year. Cat losses accounted for 30 points of the Homeowners combined ratio in the first quarter of 2015 compared to 17.9 points in the first quarter of last year. There were 9 U.S. winter storm catastrophe events in the first quarter, which affected 29 states in the District of Columbia. The majority of our losses were from burst pipes and ice damming, most of which occurred in February. While the damage was widespread across much of the eastern section of the United States, our New York and New England customers were the most affected.
Excluding the impact of catastrophes, the 2015 first quarter Homeowners combined ratio was 82.7%, a 4.3-point improvement compared to 87% in the same period a year ago. Most of the improvement is attributable to the fact that fire losses this year were in line with our 5- and 10-year averages. Whereas in the first quarter a year ago, fire losses were considerably higher than average. Not surprisingly, the impact of non-cat weather-related losses in the first quarter of 2015 was elevated compared to a typical first quarter. However, it was slightly lower than the first quarter a year ago. During the first quarter of 2015, we achieved an average Homeowners renewal rate and exposure increase of 5% in the United States compared to 6% in the fourth quarter of last year.
For our Personal Auto line, net written premiums grew 2% in the first quarter of 2015. The combined ratio was 92.9% compared to an unusually high 101.4% in the corresponding quarter of 2014. U.S. renewal policy retention in the first quarter of 2015 was a very strong 89% for both Homeowners and Personal Auto, identical to the fourth quarter of 2014.
Net written premiums for Other Personal, which includes our accident, personal excess liability and yacht lines, grew 5% in the first quarter. The combined ratio for other personal was 92.3% in the first quarter, consistent with the combined ratio of 92.4% in the first quarter a year ago.
Turning now to first quarter claims corporate wide. As we announced on April 7, we had catastrophe losses of $250 million before tax or 8.1 points on the combined ratio compared to $199 million or 6.6 points in the first quarter of 2014. The $250 million in this year's first quarter reflected about $264 million from 2015 cat events, almost entirely from the ones in the United States, slightly offset by a $14 million decrease in our estimated losses from catastrophes, which occurred in prior years. In the first quarter of this year, roughly 80% of the total catastrophe losses were attributable to CPI and 20% to CCI.
And with that, I will turn it over to Ricky, who will review our financial results in more detail.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Paul. As usual, I will discuss our financial results for the quarter, and I will also provide an update on the April 1 renewal of our major property reinsurance program. Looking first at our operating results. Underwriting income was $205 mil
componenttext:
Thank you, Paul. As usual, I will discuss our financial results for the quarter, and I will also provide an update on the April 1 renewal of our major property reinsurance program. 
Looking first at our operating results. Underwriting income was $205 million in the quarter. Property and casualty investment income after tax was down 5% to $264 million due, once again, to lower reinvestment rates in our fixed maturity portfolios and to a lesser extent, the impact of foreign currency translation. Net income was slightly higher than operating income in the quarter due to net realized investment gains before tax of $11 million or $0.03 per share after tax, including $0.03 per share from alternative investments. For comparison, in the first quarter of 2014, we had net realized investment gains before tax of $116 million or $0.30 per share after tax, including $0.14 per share from alternative investments. Unrealized depreciation before tax at March 31 was $2.9 billion compared to $2.7 billion at year-end 2014. The total carrying value of our consolidated investment portfolio was $43 billion as of March 31, 2015. The composition of our portfolio remains largely unchanged from the prior quarter. The average duration of our fixed maturity portfolio is 4.1 years, and the average credit rating is Aa3.
We continue to have excellent liquidity at the holding company. At March 31, our holding company portfolio had $1.8 billion of investments, including approximately $470 million of short-term investments. Book value per share under GAAP at March 31 was $70.33 compared to $70.12 at year-end 2014. Adjusted book value per share, which we calculate with available for sale fixed maturities at amortized costs, was, $64.75 compared to $65.03 at 2014 year end. the change in book value per share and the change in adjusted book value per share for the first quarter of 2015 both reflected an adverse impact of approximately $0.77 due to foreign currency translation.
As for loss reserves, we estimate that we had favorable development in the first quarter of 2015 on prior year reserves by SBU as follows: In CPI, we had approximately $5 million; CCI had $35 million; CSI had $70 million; and reinsurance assumed had none, bringing our total favorable development to approximately $110 million for the quarter. This represents a favorable impact on the first quarter combined ratio of about 3.5 points overall, including a favorable impact of prior year catastrophes of $14 million. For comparison, in the first quarter 2014, we had about $160 million of favorable development for the company overall, including $5 million in CPI, $90 million in CCI, $65 million in CSI and none in reinsurance assumed. The favorable impact on the combined ratio in the first quarter of 2014 was about 5.5 points, including a favorable impact of prior year catastrophes of $7 million.
For the first quarter 2015, our x-cat accident year combined ratio was 88.9% compared to 91.7% in last year's first quarter, an improvement of 2.8 points. During the first quarter, our loss reserves decreased by $107 million. The impact of foreign currency translation on loss reserves during the quarter resulted in a decrease in reserves of about $370 million, and the effect of cats was the increased reserves by $184 million.
Turning to capital management. We repurchased 3.2 million shares at an aggregate cost of $326 million during the quarter. The average cost of our repurchases in the quarter was $100.77 per share. At the end of the first quarter, we had $1 billion available for share repurchases under our current authorization, and as we've said on our last earnings call, we expect to complete this program by the end of January 2016. In addition, as John mentioned, our board raised the quarterly common stock dividend in February by 14% to $0.50 -- $0.57 per share or $2.28 on an annual basis.
I would now like to say a few words about our reinsurance program. On April 1, we renewed our major property treaties, including our North American cat treaty, our non-U.S. cat treaty and our commercial property for risk treaty. We renewed these programs with a similar limit structure to what we had in 2014 but with expanded coverage and improved terms and condition. The reinsurance market was orderly, and there was plenty of capacity meet our needs in each treaty. As you might expect, we are in an attractive steed [ph]. We achieved meaningful savings on all 3 treaties again this year with double-digit price decreases on our 2 major catastrophe treaties as well as a high single-digit price decrease on the commercial property for risk treaty.
In addition, in March, we successfully completed our seventh catastrophe bond offering to replace the maturing cat bond. The transaction was very well received by the market, and this enabled us to replace the existing limit of $250 million and expand the perils covered relative to the expiring arrangement at attractive pricing. Under this new arrangement, we purchased fully collateralized 5-year coverage to supplement our reinsurance program for our commercial and personal property exposures in the Northeast United States, running from Virginia to Maine. In terms of pricing, the coupon on the new cap bond is approximately 45% lower than the maturing bond.
Similar to our previous cat bonds, we have an indemnity-based trigger, which means that our right to collect is based on our actual incurred losses as opposed to industry- or index-based losses. We like the diversification that these cat bond arrangements bring to our overall reinsurance program, especially in our peak zone. Importantly, they provide us with a cost-effective, fully collateralized alternative to traditional reinsurance with pricing locked in for several years. 
And now I'll turn it back to John.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ricky. As you could see, the story of the quarter was a harsh winter weather in the United States, which drove catastrophe losses of $250 million. These cat losses reduced our operating income by $0.69 per share after tax. Nonetheless, we're still
componenttext:
Thanks, Ricky. As you could see, the story of the quarter was a harsh winter weather in the United States, which drove catastrophe losses of $250 million. These cat losses reduced our operating income by $0.69 per share after tax. Nonetheless, we're still able to achieve operating income of $1.57 in the quarter, reflecting strong cat performance. Our x-cat accident year combined ratio was an excellent 88.9%, which is 2.8 points of improvement over the first quarter of last year.
We are pleased with our x-currency growth of 4% in the quarter. In the U.S., retention rates remained at high levels, and we're able to achieve renewal rate increases generally in line with the prior quarter. We also continue to focus on capital management in the quarter, raising our dividend by 14% and repurchasing 3.2 million shares at an aggregate cost of $326 million.
And with that, I'll open the line to questions.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll first go to the Josh Stirling from Bernstein.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll first go to the Josh Stirling from Bernstein.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I'd love to just to talk -- start big picture around pricing. Over the past couple of years, John, I think that you talked a lot about how generally sort of conservative underwriters look to try to cover their cost of something like a 3% to 4% assumpti
componenttext: So I'd love to just to talk -- start big picture around pricing. Over the past couple of years, John, I think that you talked a lot about how generally sort of conservative underwriters look to try to cover their cost of something like a 3% to 4% assumption for long-term loss trends, and it doesn't always work out that you need all that. But with pricing now more like 1% to 2% in a lot of places, should we be thinking simplistically that, that means that the business' margins are going to start to decline? Or is really the current business really adequately priced? And at 1% to 2%, you're going to be able to run and run in place and maintain the margins over the next few years.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Josh, first, let's level set. 1% to 2% of CCI, I mean, that's a big part of our business, but it's not a majority of the business. Professional Liability was 4% in the U.S. Personal lines was 5% in the U.S. So when you look at it and if you look now for 2
componenttext: Josh, first, let's level set. 1% to 2% of CCI, I mean, that's a big part of our business, but it's not a majority of the business. Professional Liability was 4% in the U.S. Personal lines was 5% in the U.S. So when you look at it and if you look now for 2015 accident year, you're obviously also getting benefit of the lag impact of earned premium based on written premium that was higher in 2014, right? So if you look at the 2015 accident year and then you look at loss trends, which if you properly stated, 3% to 4% -- 4%, 3% is long term. We've made a point of saying but that doesn't look to be macroeconomic that'll take you to account underwriting action. We believe 2 to 3 points, let's say, 3 points is a more reasonable assumption. So if you look at that, I'd say all of our businesses in the U.S. will really probably on an earned premium basis in the 2015 accident year, a little bit margin neutral to slightly margin profit positive. With CCI, the 1 you alluded to, being margin negative to some degree, but even CCI at current rates would have a 2% -- 2-point earned premium, so it'll be only slightly negative; Professional Liability, being slightly positive in the U.S.; and Personal Lines, being 1 point or 2 point positive and a couple of points probably positive. So obviously, the challenge is in CCI, but right now it's not a terrible place to be. But overall, from our overall book, 2015 accident year does not necessarily imply margin contraction, could be margin neutral to slightly positive at today's rates in the U.S. Now you'll obviously have to make your own assumption as to where rates are going, and that could change it. Although, again, you have 5 -- you basically have 5 quarters in of the 2015 accident year already.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. I'm wondering if we could just shift gears a little bit. You guys are sort of best known for your high net worth Homeowners and Personal Lines, and someday, we all aspire to have the yachts, so that we need to -- so that you guys can insur
componenttext: That's helpful. I'm wondering if we could just shift gears a little bit. You guys are sort of best known for your high net worth Homeowners and Personal Lines, and someday, we all aspire to have the yachts, so that we need to -- so that you guys can insure us. But the question -- I sort of struggle with, just because we don't always sort of talk as much about strategy, is when you guys look long term, how -- what is -- you have a great brand today. Agents love you. You have good products, and you're sort of the one to beat. But there's a lot of energy and interest and focus sort of targeting the sector, and I'm kind of curious how you're thinking about either, I guess, strategies or maybe tactics to actually maintain your position and really continue to grow that business over time.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Josh, this is Paul. I'll take a stab at your question. First off, yes, we're all anxious to make enough to get that yacht, and sure certainly hope you get there soon, so -- but I would start off by just level setting. There is a lot of energy around the h
componenttext: Josh, this is Paul. I'll take a stab at your question. First off, yes, we're all anxious to make enough to get that yacht, and sure certainly hope you get there soon, so -- but I would start off by just level setting. There is a lot of energy around the high net worth space amongst the small handful of competitors here, especially in the United States, and I think what's exciting people about it is there is real opportunity to differentiate and to also take market share from regional carriers and from the direct writers. I would estimate that about 80% of the high-net-worth space is just large direct writers and regional carriers, often times just by default. Somebody comes out of business school and ends up being with a buddy from high school who's a local agent, and they tend to stay there for 10 or 15, 20 years. And they really don't know what an independent agent can bring to the party and what Chubb Personal Lines can bring to the party. So one of the tricks in the energy around us is to have certain campaigns that are trying to peel people out of the direct writer market. Another is to make certain that we're working very closely with our agents to educate them, so they speak the language of the high net worth and the ultra-high net worth people. We're obviously adding to our products as well so that we can service them. Clearly, our international network gives us a huge advantage when it comes to the ultra-high net worth because, as we all know, they have homes, and they park their yachts in all kinds of exotic places and that type of thing. And clearly, the fine art market is another thing. The art schedules are absolutely staggering for a lot of these families, and we have the ability to put together hundreds of millions of dollars in art coverage on a single phone call. So we have deep expertise when it comes to appraisal, to preservation. Just, for example, we have, I think, 17 fine art specialists around the globe that are working on just helping with our customers preserve those -- their fine art and that type of thing. So a lot of it is around product. A lot of it is around service, but we're working very hard to make certain that our independent agents have the ability to really sell to these families. And they know how to go out and pry them out of channels that they're currently not tapping into.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll now go to Josh Shanker from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And we'll now go to Josh Shanker from Deutsche Bank.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Not that I'm trying to get a yacht. I'm actually more on the mass affluent market, and historically, I've always thought that Chubb had a better positioning there than maybe in ultra-high net worth. Can you sort of break down -- there are 2 different prod
componenttext: Not that I'm trying to get a yacht. I'm actually more on the mass affluent market, and historically, I've always thought that Chubb had a better positioning there than maybe in ultra-high net worth. Can you sort of break down -- there are 2 different products and where Chubb is in both those products a little bit?. And when you think about -- one of your competitors mentioned that in getting new customers for their high net worth the business that the real opportunity is with people who are poorly insured by well-known carriers who aren't really high-net-worth carriers. But when I think about that, that sounds very mass affluent, like, to me, not yacht and paintings. What's the market opportunity for growth in the 2 different markets locally in the United States and internationally?

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Josh. First off, I think we break it down by -- well, we break it down a lot but in 3 broad swathes. The first is our Signature, which is the ultra-high net worth. Then we have our VIP clients, and then we have our -- what you're kind of referring
componenttext: Thanks, Josh. First off, I think we break it down by -- well, we break it down a lot but in 3 broad swathes. The first is our Signature, which is the ultra-high net worth. Then we have our VIP clients, and then we have our -- what you're kind of referring to as mass affluent. We just call them our regular Masterpiece customers. And I do think that is where a lot of the market resides that we can take away from the other channels. I'd tell you, that's one of the areas where we believe we have a real distinct advantage against the other high-net-worth carriers who are obviously trying to build some scale there. But we've had our Masterpiece product vehicle and our back office set up for over 30 years right now. So quite frankly, when an agent comes to us with a block or a book of mass affluent customers, frankly, what's so attractive is we have the back office to help them and can handle that volume. So we really have offerings for those 3 broad swathes of the market.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Is the ultra-high net worth the market underinsured currently, would be my first question. And two, in terms of the market as a whole, what percentage of the mass affluent market do you think is with the wrong kind of carrier?
componenttext: Is the ultra-high net worth the market underinsured currently, would be my first question. And two, in terms of the market as a whole, what percentage of the mass affluent market do you think is with the wrong kind of carrier?

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: As I said just taking the last piece, Josh, we think about 80% of the high-net-worth space is with carriers that don't specialize in the high-net-worth space. I'm not going to say they're with the wrong carrier because I think everybody who's not with us
componenttext: As I said just taking the last piece, Josh, we think about 80% of the high-net-worth space is with carriers that don't specialize in the high-net-worth space. I'm not going to say they're with the wrong carrier because I think everybody who's not with us is with the wrong carrier, but we can't say as you well know. So when it comes to the ultra-high net worth and are they underinsured, I would tell you'd be surprised how many of them don't, for example, carry more than, say, $5 million in excess liability coverage, and they're always shocked when we sit down with them and talk to them about our ability to handle tens of millions of dollars in excess liability. And then when we sit with them and we get them to get their artwork, for example, independently appraised, that market is absolutely on fire. And depending on their collection, it's not -- I don't see a week that goes by were somebody isn't bumping up their art schedule at least by $10 million to $15 million in value, and that's just off their current collection.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then I would get off, one last question. With all that going on, I guess, I just would imagine that you'd have more growth than we're seeing right now against that backdrop. Do you think there's a temporarily low? Or do you think that it's highly comp
componenttext: And then I would get off, one last question. With all that going on, I guess, I just would imagine that you'd have more growth than we're seeing right now against that backdrop. Do you think there's a temporarily low? Or do you think that it's highly competitive? Where is the growth going to come from?

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: When it comes from competition, I always have a hard time distinguishing between highly competitive, competitive, all the rest [ph] . I've been doing this for so long. If I was competitive, just as a basis of that, I think the trick for Chubb and the othe
componenttext: When it comes from competition, I always have a hard time distinguishing between highly competitive, competitive, all the rest [ph] . I've been doing this for so long. If I was competitive, just as a basis of that, I think the trick for Chubb and the others that are in this space will be around going after those people that are not in the channel. Clearly, it's not about just creating accounts with a couple of other carriers and taking margin out of them. So that's where I think the struggle is in the United States. Clearly, we're growing in other places. I'd say, if you're looking at our overall growth, it was down a little bit, but you have to remember that we're also overseas, and currency impacted us on the Homeowners business, in particular the Canadian dollar, the British pound and the euro, so -- and then as well the Brazilian real came down. So those currencies all impacted our growth.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question will come from Mike Nannizzi from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And our next question will come from Mike Nannizzi from Goldman Sachs.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just one -- couple quick ones. In the Personal Lines, anything unusual in the underlying there in terms of loss activity other than maybe some of the sort of cat items you mentioned or weather items you mentioned find their way into the underlying?
componenttext: Just one -- couple quick ones. In the Personal Lines, anything unusual in the underlying there in terms of loss activity other than maybe some of the sort of cat items you mentioned or weather items you mentioned find their way into the underlying?

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would tell you, Mike, that our claim trends overall were fine. Obviously, I don't think looking at them on an x-cat combined basis, but actually, our claim bounced slightly compared to our growth in premiums. So it's really outside of the weather, as Jo
componenttext: I would tell you, Mike, that our claim trends overall were fine. Obviously, I don't think looking at them on an x-cat combined basis, but actually, our claim bounced slightly compared to our growth in premiums. So it's really outside of the weather, as John said, outside the harsh weather in the winter. It really was a benign loss cost environment, and that's really across the board. I'm not just talking about Homeowners. I'm talking about claims in general. I think Worker's Compensation new arising claims were down 1%, which is terrific when you look at the growth in Workers' Compensation. And I think our new arise count all up or down about 3 to 4 points, so very good result.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Do you see a lot of reverse increase after periods like this from maybe folks that aren't your customers that are neighbors with folks that are? And do you see that sort of activity, especially given the concentration of losses here being in your footprin
componenttext: Do you see a lot of reverse increase after periods like this from maybe folks that aren't your customers that are neighbors with folks that are? And do you see that sort of activity, especially given the concentration of losses here being in your footprint?

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. I can't tell you -- we often joke, gee, we're not big on advertising, but quite frankly, when I look at the loss cost of this business, that's really where the advertising happens. Whether it's a -- there's a hailstorm, whether it's a wildfire
componenttext: Absolutely. I can't tell you -- we often joke, gee, we're not big on advertising, but quite frankly, when I look at the loss cost of this business, that's really where the advertising happens. Whether it's a -- there's a hailstorm, whether it's a wildfire, whether it's a winter storm, the way we bring clients back after, say, a burst pipe loss, it makes them whole to the fit and finish of what they had pre-loss and somebody -- other standard carriers bringing in -- giving them $13 for a roll of wallpaper, and we're bringing them back with their woven wallpaper and the rest of it. It's a huge difference, and that gets talked up throughout the affluent communities.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it, got it. And I guess, one question I have, just bigger picture, I guess, on volatility of earnings and these losses recently. I mean, obviously there's a benefit to them from sort of a marketing perspective if you will. But certainly, earnings have
componenttext: Got it, got it. And I guess, one question I have, just bigger picture, I guess, on volatility of earnings and these losses recently. I mean, obviously there's a benefit to them from sort of a marketing perspective if you will. But certainly, earnings have been more volatile for you guys and for peers, and that volatility has really picked up, again, relative to peers over the last 5 quarters or so. I mean, do you think about -- is that something that you want to try and get back into line with peers or kind of look more like either you did before or they do now from that perspective? Or do you just feel -- are you comfortable with the earnings volatility that you have even given just sort of the availability of coverage out there and the relatively attractive cost?

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'd obviously prefer less volatility if we could get it. I think we're going to be subject to a little bit more given our concentration in the Northeast and its being prone to weather disruptions. But having said that, I had a talk that we've been surpri
componenttext: We'd obviously prefer less volatility if we could get it. I think we're going to be subject to a little bit more given our concentration in the Northeast and its being prone to weather disruptions. But having said that, I had a talk that we've been surprisingly volatile the last 2 years, 5 quarters, 2 or 3 quarters. But the fact was that in 2013 we ran a 3.6 cat load, and 2014 after initial 6 point first quarter and 10 point first half, 5 points on average a year, we ran a 3.62. So we really didn't have unduly high cats over the last couple of years. If you go back a couple years before that, Sandy and Irene, obviously, which back-to-back storms like that are unprecedented, worst problems. But we've had a quarterly blip here or there, but the cats have not been unduly versus some [ph] in 2013 and 2014.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean -- I guess, I mean, so if I look at '09 to '13, you guys were running about 6 points on average for that period similar to large peer of yours. Since that point, your cat load is running about 50% higher. I guess, that's what I'm talking about
componenttext: Yes. I mean -- I guess, I mean, so if I look at '09 to '13, you guys were running about 6 points on average for that period similar to large peer of yours. Since that point, your cat load is running about 50% higher. I guess, that's what I'm talking about. It's just that from point to point maybe, it hasn't been that pronounced, but certainly, over the last 1.5 years or change, there's been just a separation, I guess, is my point. So that's what...

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: [indiscernible] run 3.5 points, so they don't -- over that period, so I don't know what the industry ran, but it can't be much, much less than that. I think, if you go back to Sandy and Irene, you can't get away from the fact that we're Northeast concentr
componenttext: [indiscernible] run 3.5 points, so they don't -- over that period, so I don't know what the industry ran, but it can't be much, much less than that. I think, if you go back to Sandy and Irene, you can't get away from the fact that we're Northeast concentrated. And the storms have taken place in the last 5 to 6 years in the Northeast. They haven't taken place in Florida. There haven't been any storms in Florida. So we have a little more volatility, but I think, again, sometimes we focus on the short terms [ph] on the quarter and forget that the last couple of years have not been all that volatile in terms of annual cat load.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: And just one additional thought there. Be careful when you're making comparisons of cat loads across companies because every company may have a slightly different definition of a catastrophe. We -- as we've said, I think, on prior calls, we tend to use th
componenttext: And just one additional thought there. Be careful when you're making comparisons of cat loads across companies because every company may have a slightly different definition of a catastrophe. We -- as we've said, I think, on prior calls, we tend to use the PCS definition in the U.S. Other companies may have their own version of what they're putting in cat, so you need to be just a little careful of that.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: The only thing I'd top -- chime in here, Mike, is that the other thing, I think, you got to keep in mind is what the bottom line is. And Homeowners, where there is volatility on a quarterly basis, when we compare our combined ratio to that of the industry
componenttext: The only thing I'd top -- chime in here, Mike, is that the other thing, I think, you got to keep in mind is what the bottom line is. And Homeowners, where there is volatility on a quarterly basis, when we compare our combined ratio to that of the industry over the period 2009 and '13, which includes Sandy and Irene, we're a full 8 points better on the combined ratio than the industry. So it's really -- that is another data point you have to keep in mind.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll now go to the Cliff Gallant from Nomura.
componenttext: We'll now go to the Cliff Gallant from Nomura.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I want to -- turning it back to the high-net-worth business, and was wondering if you can comment on your strategy in regard to the commissions that you pay your agents. And it looks to me that you're paying something along the lines of 17%, and a lot of
componenttext: I want to -- turning it back to the high-net-worth business, and was wondering if you can comment on your strategy in regard to the commissions that you pay your agents. And it looks to me that you're paying something along the lines of 17%, and a lot of your peers, to me, even those that are focused on that area of business seems like they're at least 1 point or 2 below that level. But given your -- the product's reputation, the company's reputation, I would think that you wouldn't need to pay a higher commission. Could you talk a little bit what's the thinking behind that?

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Cliff. First off, I don't know where you're coming up with the comparisons with the others in the high-net-worth space. When I look at them, I try to compare them on a by-line basis because by line really matters. For example, we have Accident & Hea
componenttext: Sure, Cliff. First off, I don't know where you're coming up with the comparisons with the others in the high-net-worth space. When I look at them, I try to compare them on a by-line basis because by line really matters. For example, we have Accident & Health embedded in our Personal Lines Other. So when I break them out by line, we're actually very, very close to what everybody else is paying. Flat 401 [ph] carrier who specializes in Florida, and when you write stand-alone Florida-only homeowners, you we don't have to pay that much in commission.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So you're -- so just [indiscernible]
componenttext: Okay. So you're -- so just [indiscernible]

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: We're very much in line, Cliff, is what I'm saying bottom line. We're not -- Again, from your point, we've got the respected brand. We're the pioneers in this high-net-worth space. We have the international network. We have the coverages and the expertise
componenttext: We're very much in line, Cliff, is what I'm saying bottom line. We're not -- Again, from your point, we've got the respected brand. We're the pioneers in this high-net-worth space. We have the international network. We have the coverages and the expertise, the ability to customize, et cetera. So gosh, I'd be awful upset with our team if they were had to pay extra commission on top of that to get business.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll now move to the Paul Newsome from Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: We'll now move to the Paul Newsome from Sandler O'Neill.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Was there any change in strategy or thoughts following this quarter's impact with currency on how you think about your businesses or think about running the investment portfolio?
componenttext: Was there any change in strategy or thoughts following this quarter's impact with currency on how you think about your businesses or think about running the investment portfolio?

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would say -- it's Ricky. I would say broadly no. We like the diversification that we get from having our international businesses. Paul mentioned we think it's a competitive advantage in a number of our business lines as well. We're very thoughtful
componenttext: Yes, I would say -- it's Ricky. I would say broadly no. We like the diversification that we get from having our international businesses. Paul mentioned we think it's a competitive advantage in a number of our business lines as well. We're very thoughtful about how we manage currency risk. We match assets and liabilities in the local currencies to try to minimize any potential currency exposures, so I would say from a strategic standpoint, no changes anticipated. We're very happy with our international operations and their overall performance.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: What I'd say that while we had a big impact on book value and a decent size impact on revenue, the impact on earnings per share was negligible. It was a couple of cents per share. So it's the price of being overseas. I don't know what the alternative woul
componenttext: What I'd say that while we had a big impact on book value and a decent size impact on revenue, the impact on earnings per share was negligible. It was a couple of cents per share. So it's the price of being overseas. I don't know what the alternative would be. I mean, it's -- currency fall up and down, and we want to be overseas. We want to be diversified. I think most people would think that's a good strategy.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I didn't mean to imply either way [indiscernible] ...
componenttext: I didn't mean to imply either way [indiscernible] ...

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, no, no, I understand, but I'd be interested in hearing what would be an alternative strategy. I mean, we do not keep undue amounts of investment assets in foreign currencies. In fact, the impact on our investment income is relatively negligible. It's
componenttext: No, no, no, I understand, but I'd be interested in hearing what would be an alternative strategy. I mean, we do not keep undue amounts of investment assets in foreign currencies. In fact, the impact on our investment income is relatively negligible. It's a point of something our overall investment income, but you do have to keep some assets there.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, the only thing I could imagine is it would maybe increase or decrease your appetite for capital allocation one way or the other.
componenttext: No, the only thing I could imagine is it would maybe increase or decrease your appetite for capital allocation one way or the other.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, not currency unless you thought it was permanent. But it's obviously more -- it is a more complicated issue. I mean, it might decrease your appetite if the economies of the countries were poor, and of course, we've had some -- Europe has had some issu
componenttext: No, not currency unless you thought it was permanent. But it's obviously more -- it is a more complicated issue. I mean, it might decrease your appetite if the economies of the countries were poor, and of course, we've had some -- Europe has had some issues. You have issues now with Brazil in terms of their economy. Currency is part and parcel of it, but as -- if economies remain strong, we can write business in the right profitable business. It won't change our strategy.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just unrelated question, I think you have a successful piece of your business where you have outsourced the claims. Maybe you could talk about sort of where you think outside the obvious maybe in the personalized business but in your commercialized busine
componenttext: Just unrelated question, I think you have a successful piece of your business where you have outsourced the claims. Maybe you could talk about sort of where you think outside the obvious maybe in the personalized business but in your commercialized business, where you think you really should have control over those claims versus places where it's not as important.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. This is Paul. I would tell you that the area where the -- where we typically use third-party administrators is in the Accident & Health business, and the reality is there. It's often times -- say, business travel accident policies will have things l
componenttext: Sure. This is Paul. I would tell you that the area where the -- where we typically use third-party administrators is in the Accident & Health business, and the reality is there. It's often times -- say, business travel accident policies will have things like a lost luggage rider on them, and this is very -- it's just not economically feasible to have a Chubb adjuster sitting in the United States handling a $5,000 piece of lost luggage. So -- and quite frankly, these programs are often sold through affinity groups, say, a bank credit card outside the United States. So -- and they're not really looking for the Chubb hand-holding empathetic claim experience. The only other places where we really use outside third-party administrators to any degree would be around large risk management accounts in the Commercial space where they actually request that, and they're breaking out their cost structure that way. I don't know, Dino, if you want to add anything to that.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, no, I think that's a good description.
componenttext: No, no, I think that's a good description.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then there's the occasional loss of a secondary home up in Alaska or something, and we -- it's just easier for us to use a third-party administrator to go up and look at that type of a claim than supply somebody up from Seattle. So that's -- we have g
componenttext: And then there's the occasional loss of a secondary home up in Alaska or something, and we -- it's just easier for us to use a third-party administrator to go up and look at that type of a claim than supply somebody up from Seattle. So that's -- we have great relationships with those people and obviously, have contracts written up with them as well. And we have what we call Chubb business consultants that oversee those individual relationships and make certain that if we use an outside vendor that they live up to our standard.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll now go to Jay Gelb from Barclays.
componenttext: We'll now go to Jay Gelb from Barclays.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: One of the other major P&C companies this quarter said that they thought that the amplitude of the commercial insurance cycle could be less severe going forward. And as pricing heads towards negative territory in commercial lines, I'm just wondering if yo
componenttext: One of the other major P&C companies this quarter said that they thought that the amplitude of the commercial insurance cycle could be less severe going forward. And as pricing heads towards negative territory in commercial lines, I'm just wondering if you would agree with that or if you have a different view.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean -- it's Dino. I mean, it's difficult to know what's going to happen. I mean, clearly, there are some things in the industry that would have you suggest that there's potentially some structural changes to the cycle, obviously the low investment retu
componenttext: I mean -- it's Dino. I mean, it's difficult to know what's going to happen. I mean, clearly, there are some things in the industry that would have you suggest that there's potentially some structural changes to the cycle, obviously the low investment returns that you make, some of the increased analytics that are being used, some of the regulatory scrutiny, et cetera. Clearly, in these last several years, if you call it a hard market, you really didn't see rate increases the way you saw them in the last hard market cycle. So hopefully, that portends that you're not going to see larger rate decreases, but we'll see. We'll have to see how the cycle plays out.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then my follow-up question is on reserve releases. If my data is correct, it looks like reserve releases of $110 million in the quarter, even including the benefit of favorable part of your cat development, is the lowest level of any quarter in
componenttext: Okay. And then my follow-up question is on reserve releases. If my data is correct, it looks like reserve releases of $110 million in the quarter, even including the benefit of favorable part of your cat development, is the lowest level of any quarter in 3 years. So I think a concern would be that this reserve release tailwind all of a sudden becomes a headwind. How are you preparing for that? And do you think that's a possible outcome?

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, coming at it from both sides, I mean, I think I've -- that often, Jay, in the past calls, especially when asked about our guidance and what's favorable development, what's implied in that, that we had no specific levels of favorable development impl
componenttext: Well, coming at it from both sides, I mean, I think I've -- that often, Jay, in the past calls, especially when asked about our guidance and what's favorable development, what's implied in that, that we had no specific levels of favorable development implied but that, over the long run, it seems hard to believe that we could indefinitely sustain 6 points of favorable development. And I proved generally wrong. Although we've had some incremental decline in favorable development, say, 1.5 points from 2010 to 2014. But that's 6.5 to 5, so it's pretty darn good. So pretty robust and I think it's fair to say, the most surprising aspect of our recent overall reserve development and actually been up significantly, it has been sustained at such strong levels. And you're right. The first quarter was 3.5 points. But development can move around quite a bit individual quarters without signaling a significant trend. So give you an example -- 2 examples, development we experienced in both the fourth quarter of 2013 and the first quarter of 2010 were $100 million to $115 million, now very similar to amount we had experienced initially at first quarter. The same concern could have been raised for those periods. As it turned out, development rebounded sharply in the ensuing quarters. So in retrospect, these less favorable development quarters turned out to be blips rather than a tipping point in the level of development. So I can't say whether or not this holds to be true with development for the balance of 2015. In the end, our reserves [indiscernible] over time is a function of actual loss experienced, which is obviously difficult to predict. But I do think it'll be -- could be very -- pretty immature to draw such a conclusion based on one quarter result.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I understand. It just seems that last -- in 2014, seasonally first quarter was the -- was a bit higher. Actually, it was pretty even over the year, but it doesn't seem like there's a seasonal factor there. Is there?
componenttext: I understand. It just seems that last -- in 2014, seasonally first quarter was the -- was a bit higher. Actually, it was pretty even over the year, but it doesn't seem like there's a seasonal factor there. Is there?

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, this year -- if we got hurt in the short-tail lines -- and there's a little bit of seasonal factor to short-term lines since they don't last long, right? So the Property, Homeowners lines, you see more development one way or another in the first quart
componenttext: No, this year -- if we got hurt in the short-tail lines -- and there's a little bit of seasonal factor to short-term lines since they don't last long, right? So the Property, Homeowners lines, you see more development one way or another in the first quarter than in the fourth quarter of a year, and this year, it wasn't -- we got a couple of big losses ascendant. It wasn't positive. It was negative effect. And last year, it was more positive, so that's the kind of [indiscernible] .

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Kai Pan from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Kai Pan from Morgan Stanley.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just one follow-up on Jay's question. You mentioned that you have some adverse development in the CCI segment in the quarter. Just wondering if you can provide a little more detail in term of the lines that the accident year as well as what loss trend act
componenttext: Just one follow-up on Jay's question. You mentioned that you have some adverse development in the CCI segment in the quarter. Just wondering if you can provide a little more detail in term of the lines that the accident year as well as what loss trend actually was above your original expectation.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Kai, it's Dino. I'll give you a little bit of additional color. In the short-tail class that John was just mentioning, obviously, the absence or presence of a few large losses, which -- can be lumpy from quarter-to-quarter to make a difference as to wheth
componenttext: Kai, it's Dino. I'll give you a little bit of additional color. In the short-tail class that John was just mentioning, obviously, the absence or presence of a few large losses, which -- can be lumpy from quarter-to-quarter to make a difference as to whether we have favorable development or adverse development in the quarter. In this year's first quarter, a couple of large fire losses that occurred late in 2014 did swing. The commercial property development adverse compared with the robust level of favorable development we had in the first quarter last year for the commercial property line. And as I stated earlier, the 5-point increase in the x-cat CCI result was mostly due to swing in property developments. So that gives you a little bit of a feel for what the amount actually is.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: And that's on the CCI side. In the other areas, so in CPI, most of the favorable development came from our Personal Auto book. Again, the Property lines were not as favorable this time around. And then in CSI, it was driven mainly, as it's been for the la
componenttext: And that's on the CCI side. In the other areas, so in CPI, most of the favorable development came from our Personal Auto book. Again, the Property lines were not as favorable this time around. And then in CSI, it was driven mainly, as it's been for the last number of quarters, driven mainly by Professional Liability, but we also were favorable in Surety as well.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's great. Then on your guidance and it looks like the first quarter cats accounted probably, by my calculation, probably roughly about, like 50% of your full year budget in your original guidance. So I just wonder, is that -- you didn't change y
componenttext: Okay, that's great. Then on your guidance and it looks like the first quarter cats accounted probably, by my calculation, probably roughly about, like 50% of your full year budget in your original guidance. So I just wonder, is that -- you didn't change your guidance this time, you said, because likely your confidence in the remainder of the year you will catch up or it's a just timing issue. Your typical update your guidance at the second quarter earnings.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I'm not sure I can ever say I'm confident about what cats are going to look like. I would say that one quarter certainly, as you heard John say, does not a year make, and he used the example. I'll use it as well. But last year in the first quarter,
componenttext: Well, I'm not sure I can ever say I'm confident about what cats are going to look like. I would say that one quarter certainly, as you heard John say, does not a year make, and he used the example. I'll use it as well. But last year in the first quarter, we had over 6.5 points of catastrophe losses, and we ended up the year at only 3.6 points of losses, which were below our expectations coming into the year. So we're not revisiting guidance at this time. We're not reaffirming guidance at this time. As you point out, we normally do relook at guidance at midyear, and we'll potentially address this then. But at this point, it's way too premature.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Lastly, if I may, your reinsurance program looks like the pricing have come down quite a bit. So what's your thought about like buying more reinsurance that lower your limits and could potentially lower your earnings volatility?
componenttext: Okay. Lastly, if I may, your reinsurance program looks like the pricing have come down quite a bit. So what's your thought about like buying more reinsurance that lower your limits and could potentially lower your earnings volatility?

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, what I'd say and I think I'd said this on a couple of recent calls, we're always looking at ways to potentially use reinsurance if we think it makes sense to either lower volatility or help our growth or help our bottom line results. We're quite com
componenttext: Well, what I'd say and I think I'd said this on a couple of recent calls, we're always looking at ways to potentially use reinsurance if we think it makes sense to either lower volatility or help our growth or help our bottom line results. We're quite comfortable with the reinsurance program we have today. We're constantly looking at new ideas. We've put a couple of things in place in some of our businesses. But we've never been heavy users of reinsurance, and we're not going to change our overall strategy the way that we approach the business. We are generally gross underwriters, and we'll use reinsurance if we think it helps us. But it's never that simple to just say it's cheaper today and therefore, it makes sense. We don't like giving away profitability if we don't need to.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: And I'd say from the first quarter, I mean, there'd be no reinsurance program that would have mitigated our cost. I mean, the biggest storm was $150 million. I mean, no one, I mean, in the industry is carrying first dollar coverage on reinsurance. I mean,
componenttext: And I'd say from the first quarter, I mean, there'd be no reinsurance program that would have mitigated our cost. I mean, the biggest storm was $150 million. I mean, no one, I mean, in the industry is carrying first dollar coverage on reinsurance. I mean, that would be extremely expensive. So this isn't the type of storm or type of cat losses that usually is subject to have a reinsurance coverage on. The storms aren't that big.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, as I -- this is Paul. As I mentioned before, this line contains our A&H portfolio, and the expense ratio will move up or down based on how much more or less A&H business we write in each period. And since A&H typically has a higher expense ratio but
componenttext: Yes, as I -- this is Paul. As I mentioned before, this line contains our A&H portfolio, and the expense ratio will move up or down based on how much more or less A&H business we write in each period. And since A&H typically has a higher expense ratio but obviously has a lower loss ratio profile than the other CPI businesses. But then even within the accident business, there can be real fluctuation driven primarily by the volume of the affinity accident business that I talked about before, where we're sourcing through, say, a department store or a credit card issuer, that type of a thing because, that's where we have the highest expense ratio in all of our accident business, so really depending upon the affinity volume within the overall mix of the accident and then accident within the other personal. But that's where you see the expense ratio move up and down a little bit. Bottom line, it came down a little bit because of the movement within accident, but I won't suggest that, that's a bellwether or a new low that we're going to be running with in the future.

componenttext: I think it was reasonably across the board, but I wouldn't point to it as the beginning of a trend. It was a good quarter. Quarters fluctuate. And given the fact we're not getting a sizable amount of rate overseas, it'd be hard to say that there's going to be huge improvements on a term line basis. Obviously, quarters fluctuate by loss experience, and a lot of it is luck. I think we have good underwriting in place. But I wouldn't read too much into it. I think the last few quarters were a little high. This one was probably pretty good. We'll see.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then just one more, I guess, just sort of bigger picture just on capital return philosophy. I guess, last quarter, you guys gave us a share repurchase authorization. It was a little less than last year. And then I think you also indicated you
componenttext: Got it. And then just one more, I guess, just sort of bigger picture just on capital return philosophy. I guess, last quarter, you guys gave us a share repurchase authorization. It was a little less than last year. And then I think you also indicated you felt good about excess capital position. And I think you said that the reason it was a little less than last year was you like to be able to move it around maybe based on what the share price is. Just curious if Chubb would consider deployment of capital in some other form other than share repo. And I guess, longer term along those lines, how does Chubb think about the right amount of capital that's required to kind of support the risk to this business through the cycle? And how does that compare to the way the businesses is currently capitalized?

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. It's Ricky, I'll take a shot at answering that. First off, I think what we said last quarter when we announced the new share repurchase was that it's sort of in line with what our expected earnings are for the year less shareholder dividends. And th
componenttext: Sure. It's Ricky, I'll take a shot at answering that. First off, I think what we said last quarter when we announced the new share repurchase was that it's sort of in line with what our expected earnings are for the year less shareholder dividends. And that's sort of the overall philosophy. And I'd say it wasn't the stock price that drove the size of our share repurchase. We have a philosophy that we've articulated over the last few years that our intent, obviously, market conditions and other things all being equal, that our share buyback, in essence, be in line with our earnings less shareholder dividend. And that's how we came up with the size of the program. We do believe that we are in a very strong excess capital position. We do -- we think very -- we think a lot about our deployment of capital and what's the right amount. We -- and we think about all the different types of capital deployment strategies. We're very comfortable with our share repurchase. In years past, if you looked at what we've done, when we've had more opportunity from a valuation or others, we might do something slightly larger than our earnings less dividends. So we're very careful on how we manage it, and we're very aware of being good stewards of our capital for our shareholders. So we do think about all the different options. I'm not going to comment on which ones we may or may not think about in the future. I'll also point out, as John mentioned, we've increased our common dividend for the last 33 years, which is another piece of how we manage our capital position. So again, in sum, we feel very good about where we are and the way we approach this and nothing really different than what we've been doing over a number of years.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Most of my questions have been answered. Just one quick one. The currency impact, as you think short term the next several quarters, would you expect the impact on premiums from the stronger dollar to be similar to the first quarter, stronger or weaker?
componenttext: Most of my questions have been answered. Just one quick one. The currency impact, as you think short term the next several quarters, would you expect the impact on premiums from the stronger dollar to be similar to the first quarter, stronger or weaker?

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think it's obviously -- it depends on the comparison of the movement of currency quarter-to-quarter. I would think that in the second and third quarters -- remember, most of the currency movement that has happened started in the fourth quarter of last y
componenttext: I think it's obviously -- it depends on the comparison of the movement of currency quarter-to-quarter. I would think that in the second and third quarters -- remember, most of the currency movement that has happened started in the fourth quarter of last year and then continued into the first quarter of this year. So all other things being equal, currency stays where it was at the end of March, then you will still see an impact on growth in certainly the second and third quarters. And I'm not saying whether it'd be similar to what we had in the first quarter. I don't know. But certainly, there will be an impact. We did -- in the guidance that we put out in January, we did say that we expect a 2-point impact for the full year, so maybe that can give you some help there as well. As John mentioned, from an earnings perspective, it doesn't have a very large impact on a quarterly basis, a couple of cents a share in the first quarter. Bear in mind, when you think about the investment income piece, a large part of our after-tax investment income comes from the municipal bond portfolio here in the U.S., so it's a slightly disproportionate impact on investment income in the U.S. Last point I'd make on book value is, again, if currencies don't change from where they were at the end of March, which is a pretty big assumption, the impact on book value will probably be meaningfully less in the second quarter than it was in the first quarter. It won't be 0 because we have some of our foreign operations that report on a 1-quarter lag, which we've highlighted in our 10-K. So there will be an impact, but it shouldn't be nearly as large as it was in the first quarter. Hopefully, that gives you some help.
