componenttext: So 3 things, 3 points, so you wouldn't be far off.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, terrific. And then last question, I'm just curious, on your CCI business, you talk about rate activity in the U.S. What is it looking like internationally?
componenttext: Okay, terrific. And then last question, I'm just curious, on your CCI business, you talk about rate activity in the U.S. What is it looking like internationally?

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. As I mentioned, the -- we're getting probably flat to slightly positive rate activity, and our retention ratios outside the U.S. are essentially close to what they are in the U.S., sort of mid-80s to 85%, 86%, 87%. The rate -- it's interesting. The r
componenttext: Yes. As I mentioned, the -- we're getting probably flat to slightly positive rate activity, and our retention ratios outside the U.S. are essentially close to what they are in the U.S., sort of mid-80s to 85%, 86%, 87%. The rate -- it's interesting. The rate has been quite stable actually. They've been traditionally lower than the increases we were getting in the U.S., but it's essentially stayed there. So it's in the flat to slightly positive.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ryan Tunis from Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ryan Tunis from Crédit Suisse.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I guess, my first question was, I guess, also on some of the PYD and in particular, I guess, in Commercial. I know you guys said that the combined ratio -- I'm sorry, this is in commercial casualty, the combined ratio there was a little elevated, but i
componenttext: So I guess, my first question was, I guess, also on some of the PYD and in particular, I guess, in Commercial. I know you guys said that the combined ratio -- I'm sorry, this is in commercial casualty, the combined ratio there was a little elevated, but it was kind of in line with last year. Was there any environmental toxic waste or asbestos-type stuff that was in there this quarter?

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Small amount. Yes, we incurred $1 million of asbestos losses and $5 million of environmental losses in the first quarter.
componenttext: Small amount. Yes, we incurred $1 million of asbestos losses and $5 million of environmental losses in the first quarter.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it, okay. And then it looked like to me that underwriting results outside of the United States actually looked pretty strong this quarter relative to kind of where they have been running. And I guess, just curious how much of that you would either con
componenttext: Got it, okay. And then it looked like to me that underwriting results outside of the United States actually looked pretty strong this quarter relative to kind of where they have been running. And I guess, just curious how much of that you would either consider unusually strong versus -- I know guys have taken some underwriting actions there. And also, where did you guys tend to see the help from that? Was that in Personal Lines or Commercial or Specialty?

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think pretty well everywhere.
componenttext: I think pretty well everywhere.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think it was reasonably across the board, but I wouldn't point to it as the beginning of a trend. It was a good quarter. Quarters fluctuate. And given the fact we're not getting a sizable amount of rate overseas, it'd be hard to say that there's going t
componenttext: I think it was reasonably across the board, but I wouldn't point to it as the beginning of a trend. It was a good quarter. Quarters fluctuate. And given the fact we're not getting a sizable amount of rate overseas, it'd be hard to say that there's going to be huge improvements on a term line basis. Obviously, quarters fluctuate by loss experience, and a lot of it is luck. I think we have good underwriting in place. But I wouldn't read too much into it. I think the last few quarters were a little high. This one was probably pretty good. We'll see.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then just one more, I guess, just sort of bigger picture just on capital return philosophy. I guess, last quarter, you guys gave us a share repurchase authorization. It was a little less than last year. And then I think you also indicated you
componenttext: Got it. And then just one more, I guess, just sort of bigger picture just on capital return philosophy. I guess, last quarter, you guys gave us a share repurchase authorization. It was a little less than last year. And then I think you also indicated you felt good about excess capital position. And I think you said that the reason it was a little less than last year was you like to be able to move it around maybe based on what the share price is. Just curious if Chubb would consider deployment of capital in some other form other than share repo. And I guess, longer term along those lines, how does Chubb think about the right amount of capital that's required to kind of support the risk to this business through the cycle? And how does that compare to the way the businesses is currently capitalized?

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. It's Ricky, I'll take a shot at answering that. First off, I think what we said last quarter when we announced the new share repurchase program was that it's sort of in line with what our expected earnings are for the year less shareholder dividends
componenttext: Sure. It's Ricky, I'll take a shot at answering that. First off, I think what we said last quarter when we announced the new share repurchase program was that it's sort of in line with what our expected earnings are for the year less shareholder dividends. And that's sort of the overall philosophy. And I'd say it wasn't the stock price that drove the size of our share repurchase. We have a philosophy that we've articulated over the last few years that our intent, obviously, market conditions and other things all being equal, that our share buyback, in essence, be in line with our earnings less shareholder dividend. And that's how we came up with the size of the program. We do believe that we are in a very strong excess capital position. We do -- we think very -- we think a lot about our deployment of capital and what's the right amount. We -- and we think about all the different types of capital deployment strategies. We're very comfortable with our share repurchase. In years past, if you looked at what we've done, when we've had more opportunity from a valuation perspective or others, we might do something slightly larger than our earnings less dividends. So we're very careful on how we manage it, and we're very aware of being good stewards of our capital for our shareholders. So we do think about all the different options. I'm not going to comment on which ones we may or may not think about in the future. I'll also point out, as John mentioned, we've increased our common dividend for the last 33 years, which is another piece of how we manage our capital position. So again, in sum, we feel very good about where we are and the way we approach this and nothing really different than what we've been doing over a number of years.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our final question will come from Jay Cohen from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: And our final question will come from Jay Cohen from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Most of my questions have been answered. Just one quick one. The currency impact, as you think short term the next several quarters, would you expect the impact on premiums from the stronger dollar to be similar to the first quarter, stronger or weaker?
componenttext: Most of my questions have been answered. Just one quick one. The currency impact, as you think short term the next several quarters, would you expect the impact on premiums from the stronger dollar to be similar to the first quarter, stronger or weaker?

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think it's obviously -- it depends on the comparison of the movement of currency quarter-to-quarter. I would think that in the second and third quarters -- remember, most of the currency movement that has happened started in the fourth quarter of last y
componenttext: I think it's obviously -- it depends on the comparison of the movement of currency quarter-to-quarter. I would think that in the second and third quarters -- remember, most of the currency movement that has happened started in the fourth quarter of last year and then continued into the first quarter of this year. So all other things being equal, currency stays where it was at the end of March, then you will still see an impact on growth in certainly the second and third quarters. And I'm not saying whether it'd be similar to what we had in the first quarter. I don't know. But certainly, there will be an impact. We did -- in the guidance that we put out in January, we did say that we expect a 2-point impact for the full year, so maybe that can give you some help there as well. As John mentioned, from an earnings perspective, it doesn't have a very large impact on a quarterly basis, a couple of cents a share in the first quarter. Bear in mind, when you think about the investment income piece, a large part of our after-tax investment income comes from the municipal bond portfolio here in the U.S., so it's a slightly disproportionate impact on investment income in the U.S. Last point I'd make on book value is, again, if currencies don't change from where they were at the end of March, which is a pretty big assumption, the impact on book value will probably be meaningfully less in the second quarter than it was in the first quarter. It won't be 0 because we have some of our foreign operations that report on a 1-quarter lag, which we've highlighted in our 10-K. So there will be an impact, but it shouldn't be nearly as large as it was in the first quarter. Hopefully, that gives you some help.

headline: The Chubb Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015

componenttext: Great. Operator, I think we're finished.
